Wednesday, 18 September 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4623 Wednesday, 18 September 1996 Second Reading Debate resumed from 12 September, on motion by Mr Abbott: That the bill be now read a second time. Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulation) Amendment Bill. This bill will extend the time available for international education and training providers to become registered. Registration requires accreditation and approval by the respective state or territory where the agency operates. As well, it imposes financial conditions on private education providers. Australia's commitment to international education commenced in the 1950s when numbers of Commonwealth students were educated under the Colombo Plan. The aim was to assist Commonwealth developing countries by training their future leaders. In those days there was no expectation or understanding that there was a two-way benefit for the country. The education was expected to be of greatest assistance to those who were students. In the 1970s, restrictions were placed on quotas of international student enrolments. In the 1980s, Britain, once the favoured destination for Commonwealth and other Southern Hemisphere students, introduced full cost recovery fees to their universities. In response to that, Australia's international student enrolments grew hugely and the country was seen as offering a low cost, high quality education in a stable and mostly welcoming society. Of course, this sudden influx of overseas students brought quite heated public debate about overcrowding in universities and the costs of educating these non-Australian students. Two significant reports came out in the mid-1980s. The Golding report saw mutual advantage accruing to domestic and overseas students; it very much saw this as something important for our nation. The increase in international understanding and goodwill was seen as a very good outcome. The Jackson report took a more commercial view-that international education was a potentially significant export industry for Australia. So it advocated a free market approach to m<!ximise returns for competing institutions. In 1986 we saw deregulation of the tertiary education sector. This allowed non-residents to purchase education on a full fee-paying basis in Australia. Under the federal government's national unified education policy, the number of tertiary education providers increased hugely. The response to deregulation saw the numbers of international students increase by over 100 per cent between 1980 and 1987, with most of these students coming from Asia or Oceania. At that time there was ineffectual regulation and very little monitoring of parts of the industry-in particular, those that offered English language education and training. At the same time, student visas were often used to short-circuit immigration procedures. This led, as most of us know, to a very damaging international education crisis. The reverberations of this disaster lasted for a very long time. In particular, Asian markets looked at our smaller private

speaker: Mrs Stone (Murray) (10.18 A.m.)
theText: I rise to support the Education Services for Overseas4624 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 18 September 1996 institutions as a high risk for their sons and daughters. Many were left with fees paid but no service offered, and they could get very little action from the government of the day for quite some time. When I worked at the University of Melbourne as a manager of international development in the 1990s, when I was overseas I was often asked by parents whether it was all right to come and study under the ELICOS program in Australia. They were only too aware of friends and relations who had been damaged by fees paid and students left stranded in Australia. This bill is extremely important in that it seeks to ensure that all providers of education to international students have a quality offering and that they also have financial regulation in place so that such an embarrassing crisis can never occur again. In Australia, we now recognise that our overseas students are of enormous benefit to our current and future situation as a nation situated in Asia. For example, our educational and professional development is enhanced when students in Australia mix with future business partners and professional partners, as the global expansion of our markets takes our next generation well beyond Australia's shores. Anyone doing business today understands the significance of interpersonal networks that take time to develop. If Australian and non-Australian students work together on courses for three to four years, friendships and networks can begin in their youth. That is of enormous significance and potential advantage as those two groups grow up and share their friendships into later life. That is also important for our cultural and diplomatic objectives. Education in Australia is known elsewhere in the world to be of a high quality. Some of our leading institutions have the most prestigious research institutions in the world. For us to offer places to students to share in the learning in those agencies is substantially appreciated by many families in Hong Kong, Singapore and mainland China. It is also a form of development aid that we can offer to overseas nations, helping students to do courses in Australia which, when they go back to their own countries, will assist their nations to grow and develop. That is a very important part of our aid. Of course, the enhanced research outcomes that come from international education in Australia are good for both the research outcomes in themselves and for our international reputation. As a result of these students coming to Australia, we also have substantial economic benefits. Overseas students in this country expend something like $1 billion a year on goods and services and some $700 million on course fees. The multiplier effect of their purchases in this country increases our domestic markets. It is an exceptionally good thing for our economy to have many more people within this nation buying goods and services. Some 86 per cent of our students come from Asian countries. The majority of those-74 per cent-are enrolled in universities, but others are at TAFE colleges, secondary colleges, primary schools and English language intensive courses for overseas students-our ELICOS programs. We are clearly in a situation where the reputation of our educational offerings is what is most important as we compete with other nations in offering these educational services. People in Asia or Europe can now choose between New Zealand, the United States, Canada and the various Australian states when they make their choices about where to buy education for their sons or daughters. Wednesday, 18 September 1996 MAIN COMMITIEE 4625 Australia's reputation as a nation which offers high quality education and institutions in a very carefully regulated environment is extremely important as the parents and students choose where they will go. Therefore, this bill is of critical importance. It extends for several years the time that an institution may take to become registered. It is, without a doubt, one of the most important things we can do to safeguard the reputation of our nation for years to come. SoI am very pleased to support this bill. I believe that, as overseas students receive an education here, or in Malaysia or Thailand where we have taken some of our campuses offshore, they may perhaps come back to Australia in years to come as business people or as people applying for full-time residency. This will be significant for the Australian economy, for our culture and for our reputation as a nation that pulls its weight in the world. I commend this bill to honourable members. Education, Training and Youth Affairs) (10.27 a.m.)-in replyMr Deputy Speaker, as members are aware, this is a very simple and very straightforward bill. It extends the operation of tuition assurance schemes for a further two years. These are excellent arrangements. Since their introduction in 1993, all students have received the tuition they have paid for or have been refunded their fees. As a result of these arrangements, the Commonwealth has not been called upon to provide financial support to students where a provider has been unable or unwilling to meet its commitments. So they are very good arrangements. They have the support of the educational industry. They have the wholehearted support of education providers. I am delighted to see that they have the support of the opposition as well as that of the government. I thank the shadow minister for his contribution to the debate, I thank members on both sides for their contributions to the debate, and I am delighted to know that the education industry is progressing so well in the electorates of honourable members. I commend this bill to honourable members. Question resolved in the affirmative. Bill read a second time. Bill-by leave-reported to the House without amendment. attention of honourable members of the Main Committee to the presence in the gallery of Mr David Doige, Deputy Principal Clerk of the Public Bill Office of the House of Commons at Westminster. This is the first day of a brief attachment to this department by Mr Doige. On your behalf, I welcome him and trust that his stay in Canberra is constructive and enjoyable. theText: Order! Before calling the clerk, I draw the4626 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 18 September 1996 (1) the Budget betrays the Australian promise of working towards a more fair, just, inclusive and united society; (2) the Budget is both mindless and heartless, and its prescriptions are not what the Australian economy needs at present; (3) the Budget will have a savagely contractionary impact on economic growth and make impossible the job creation necessary to reduce Australia's still unacceptably high level of unemployment; (4) with stronger economic growth the Budget could be restored to underlying balance over the life of this Parliament through a much more moderate program of fiscal consolidation; (5) the spending cuts and tax increases contained in the Budget are, on the evidence of the Government's own Budget Papers, not necessary to reduce the Commonwealth Government's debt-to-GDP ratio and will not produce a significant improvement in the current account deficit; (6) the Budget not only offers no hope to the unemployed but actively harms their prospects of finding a job by cutting labour market programs and privati sing the previously publicly provided employment service function of the CES; (7) the Budget will have unfair and unjust consequences for the struggling and disadvantaged in our midst-the poor, the old, the sick, indigenous Australians and newly-arrived migrants; (8) the many spending cuts concerned with education and training, research and development, trade development (including breaches of promise with respect to EMDG, ITES and lAMP), production bounties, and other business support, will be counter-productive in their longer term consequences; (9) there is deception involved in the family tax package contained in the Budget, whereby what the Prime Minister appears to be putting into one pocket is for most middle Australian families being taken right out of the other by the Treasurer in higher education fees, Austudy changes, higher nursing home charges, higher fees and charges; (10) there are many breaches of Coalition election promises contained in this Budget, which amount to over $17 billion over four years, and which will cause hardship, insecurity, and dismay for millions of Australians; (11) the Budget involves a massive betrayal of regional Australia through the abolition of the $150 million regional development programme, large cuts to road funding, the closure of regional Government offices such as Medicare and CES offices, and the cuts to the ABC and university funding; (12) the mean-spirited decision to introduce large, up-front entry fees and massively increased daily fees for nursing homes, and increase user-charges will harm elderly Australians; (13) the abolition of Childcare Operational Subsidies will impact heavily upon community based child care centres; (14) the reduction of $800 million over four years in public hospital funding will cause longer waiting lists for the sick and reduce the quality of hospital and medical assistance for millions of people; (15) the Budget involves a breaking of the Government's so called 'core' commitment to maintain Medicare in its entirety through cuts to rebates for numerous items under Medicare; (16) the cruel decision to abolish the Commonwealth Dental Health Programme will cause serious problems for the less well off; (17) harsh and promise-breaking decisions will force Australian families to pay substantially more for the cost of their prescription medicines; (18) the massive funding cuts to education, the increased HECS charges and AUSTUDY changes will penalise the less well-off; (19) the Budget's comprehensive and ideological assault on the public sector will cost 10,500 jobs in 1996-97 alone; I..-l Wednesday, 18 September 1996 MAIN COMMITfEE 4627 (20) the Government has failed to honour its election commitment to maintain the environment budget and to provide an additional $84 million in the 1996-97 Budget, instead cutting by 13 per cent the environmental budget and forward estimates; (21) the reckless decision to reduce funding for the National Highway by $622 million over four years, breaches a clear Coalition election commitment at the 1996 election, and with other decisions will reduce the level of public infrastructure investment, especially in regional Australia; (22) the decision to impose a 500 per cent increase in the taxation arrangements for visits to the Great Barrier Reef will discourage tourism and cost jobs in Queensland; (23) the Government has failed to honour its promise to not cut Australia's foreign aid beyond the election commitment to abolish the DIFF program, and in doing so will allow the estimated ODAlGDP ratio for Australia in 1996-97 to fall to 0.29 per cent; (24) the Government has failed to honour its election promise that Defence expenditure would not be cut, whilst cutting $165 million from the 1995 Defence Budget estimates for 1996-97, and reducing Defence expenditure as a percentage of GDP to its lowest level since 1939; (25) the mean-spirited and discriminatory approach to migrants and ethnic communities will harm outworkers, hurt newly-arrived migrants and refugees, cut humanitarian aid and penalise asylum seekers; (26) the substantial cuts to ATSIC and to indigenous-related Commonwealth programs represent a massive setback to the process of reconciliation in Australia; (27) the savage cuts to the ABC, of $209 million over four years, are in complete breach of the Coalition's solemn election promise to maintain existing levels of Commonwealth funding to the ABC; (28) the Budget has failed to honour the promise to maintain levels of arts funding and spend an additional $60 million over three years; and (29) the Government's plan to substantially increase Commonwealth court and tribunal fees, coupled with deep cuts to legal aid, will result in a severe curtailment of access to justice by many Australians" . Appropriation Bill (No.1). The appropriations set the scene for a better future for Australia. As the Treasurer ( Mr Costello) mentioned in his budget speech, the focus is on savingssavings for investment, sustainable growth and real jobs. The first observation I would like to make is that this is a budget that has been welcomed by middle Australia. They know that this budget turns around the failures of the past and sets this country on track for the future. They know that we cannot live forever beyond our means on the bankcard with ever growing debt. Mainstream Australia understands that hard decisions have to be made and, more importantly, they expect a responsible government to do just that. The coalition went to the election promising a better deal for families, for small businesses, for real jobs, for older Australians. As well as that, we promised improvements to our health care system and to fix this country's financial system. All of these things have been achieved in this budget. We have, indeed, delivered just that. I take this opportunity to congratulate the Treasurer on the budget, a budget that is strong but fair. This government has fulfilled its major promises that we took to the Australian electorate in March this year. The Australian people will not forget that it was the previous Labor government, those members opposite, who took great pains to hide the true state of the nation's financial situation from the Australian people. The Labor government hid the fact that the budget outcome for the past year was a deficit of over $10 billion. Such financial dishonesty should never be inflicted on the Australian public again. Therefore, I applaud the

speaker: Mrs Johnston (Canning) (10.30 A.m.)
theText: I rise today to speak to the government's4628 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 18 September 1996 Treasurer for initiating the charter of budget honesty that will require a government to make the Australian people aware of the real state of the Treasury's books before they cast their vote. The financial burden left by 13 years of Labor mismanagement is shared fairly by asking high income earners as well as business to make a contribution. This huge debt problem created by the previous Labor government could not be ignored by this new government, so we have taken the responsibility of fixing that problem, and the Australian people are backing us all the way. Let me refer to an opinion poll published in the Bulletin magazine of 3 September 1996, conducted after the budget was handed down and when Australians had had a chance to digest its contents. Seventy-seven per cent of respondents view the budget as average or better. Even 60 per cent of Labor's voters agree. This detailed Morgan poll shows the high level of trust the Australian people have in this government. We have honoured our major election commitments while achieving a major turnaround in the nation's finances. Our central election commitment was to Australia's families. One of our highest priorities as a government is to relieve the financial pressures on low and middle income families with children. In January this year, while I was campaigning in the seat that I now represent, I produced a report called Canning chasm, which looked at the incomes of families in the electorate of Canning. The report was drawn from Australian Bureau of Statistics data outlining the inequality between families on different incomes in the south-eastern suburbs of Perth. According to the ABS data, 14.5 per cent of families living in Canning were surviving on incomes of $16,000 or less. Meanwhile, 11 per cent were living on incomes of over $60,000 per annum. This showed the electorate of Canning to be an area that had a great disparity between families who were well-off and those battlers who struggled daily to make ends meet. The people I represent in Canning have told me time and time again, as I meet with them around the electorate, that they are very pleased with this budget. And these people represent middle Australia, the battlers to whom we promised a better deal in the election campaign. The people of Canning also understand that our family tax initiative will really benefit them. This initiative will assist almost two million Australian families and recognises the financial sacrifices made by those families with young children where one parent stays at home. This will provide a great deal of additional assistance for families in my electorate of Canning, as I am sure it will also do to many other families in many other members' electorates. " The family tax initiative, along with other budget initiatives such as the health insurance tax rebate, funding for marriage and relationship education and parenting education programs will all go a long way to helping these families.-, In addition to that, there will also be an increase of $5 million a year for emergency relief ' funding to welfare agencies who help those families who are most in need. This will alleviate . the pressure that the majority of Australian families have been feeling over recent years. , Australians know our central election commitment was to look after families and we, I believe, have truly met that commitment. This is also a budget that acknowledges the needs of women and issues such as child care and balancing work and family. Of course these concerns are not unique to women and there are many men who also juggle these commitments today. But women now represent 43 per cent of the paid work force and many women spend different periods of time in and out of the labour market mainly due to family concerns. Through this government's initiatives on Wednesday, 18 September 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4629 family tax measures, freeing up the industrial relations system, making superannuation easier and breaking new ground in marriage and family support, women will benefit greatly. The coalition also campaigned to give Australians real jobs. This budget takes responsibility for getting employment on track again by helping small business to get back on its feet. Small business is the backbone of the Australian economy, and it is small business that employs the majority of Australians. I note with interest the report and an editorial in the Australian Financial Review on 16 September 1996 reporting that Australia has lost the equivalent of $12 billion in export earnings, forgone partly because of our decline in competitiveness. The Financial Review states: The previous Labor Government must take the blame for much of this problem. In its final years it has failed to drive forward with those micro-economic reforms that could have made Australian businesses more flexible and competitive in export markets. The Financial Review goes on to ask how the business sector can reach its full potential when, and I quote: It is hobbled by a regulatory environment that impedes our international competitiveness. The newspaper also notes that the Howard government has already taken initiatives in this area and indeed we have. Our workplace reform legislation and our package of measures to help business will go a long way to strengthen this sector. The government has already met its commitment to reduce the provisional tax uplift factor to 6 per cent. This means that small business is no longer assessed for provisional tax on income in excess of what it has earned. The capital gains tax rollover relief that was announced in the budget will allow small business to rollover their business assets without capital gains tax disincentive. This government's industrial relation reforms currently before the parliament will rectify the job-destroying unfair dismissal laws. I recently sent a small business survey to all small and large or medium sized businesses in my electorate of Canning, and there are approximately 3,000 of them. I asked them, 'If you could fix any problem to help your business or create jobs what would it be?' The most common answer that I got was to fix the unfair dismissal laws brought in by the previous Labor government. Many other business owners also mentioned the fact that they would like to take on apprentices if it was made more feasible for them to do so. Therefore, one aspect that I am particularly pleased with is the apprenticeship scheme announced in this year's budget. The allocation of almost $260 million in incentive payments and wage subsidies will provide real jobs and a real future for young Australians. This government will deliver real jobs-not revolving door training programs which have left people, particularly our youth, despondent about their future and their worth. Under Labor, the number of apprenticeships dropped to its lowest level in 30 years. In government they favoured countless training programs with fancy names and not much else. They did not work and, unfortunately, many of the people who went through these schemes did not end up working either. As I mentioned before, the coalition made it clear during the election campaign that one of its central priorities was to tackle Australia's high level of youth unemployment. I believe that the apprenticeship system has always been a tried and true method of getting young Australians into real jobs and I am pleased to see a return to this system. 4630 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 18 September 1996 The budget is about creating real jobs. We are not going to con the unemployed as Labor did. Their training schemes were, in the main, unsuccessful. Sadly, too many people ended up back where they started: unemployed and without a job. It was a cruel and callous hoax. This was a disgusting and totally irresponsible and immoral scam by the previous Labor government, the so-called champion of the unemployed. This government is not going to use the unemployed as pawns in some gigantic chess game. We in the Howard coalition government have genuine compassion for the unemployed, and we are determined to provide a far better future for them. Let me quote an article published in the Economist on April 6, 1996. Listen very carefully, on the other side. The article says: In a growing body of research, economists have compared groups of unemployed people who enter government training schemes with similar groups who do not. In almost every case, these studies have found that the schemes have failed to improve either the earnings or the employment prospects of their clients. After surveying the results of various broadly based training programs for unemployed adults, the training-friendly OECD was forced to conclude in 1994 that there is 'remarkably meagre support for the hypothesis that such programs are effective.' By easing the burden on small business, by introducing the modem Australian apprenticeship and traineeship scheme, by introducing employment placement enterprises, and by opening these enterprises up to the private sector, we will be creating real jobs for the unemployed. For the first time in 13 years, the unemployed have real hope that they will be able to get a job. The article in the Economist again says: Of five Australian training programs studied during 1989-92, only one could reportonly one, mind youthat at least half of its participants were either working or studying three months after completion. Who was in power in 1989-92? The members opposite: that is who was in power-the members opposite, who grew increasingly out of touch with reality and who had no real plan to fix the problem they had helped create. Our jobs pathway guarantee program will take school students and give them active work experience and the opportunity to take on apprenticeships or traineeships while still at school, to adequately prepare themselves to adapt to working life. Germany leads the world with this type of scheme, called the 'dual-education system'. Many German 16-year-olds sign an apprenticeship contract with local firms to work part-time in training positions. The rest of the time, they go to a vocational school. These apprenticeships are not necessarily only for traditional trades or skilled jobs: they also include white-collar and professional occupations. It is a company apprenticeship scheme that is tied to the educational system. When the apprentice/pupils finish, most get jobs either with their employer or, at the very least, in the field in which they had trained. This scheme works, just as the jobs pathway guarantee program will work, by allowing the education system and industry to work hand in hand to quickly respond to industry needs. This government is committed to the youth of Australia. It is going to be a very difficult task to raise the standard of literacy and numeracy skills, which has been very much in decline in recent years in Australia. There is presently a new Western Australian designed program that is being piloted at East Maddington Primary School and at other schools in my electorate of Canning. Called 'Reading for sure', the program was developed by Perth clinical psychologist Dr Julia Solomon, in an attempt to reduce anxiety in children who were afraid to read for fear of making mistakes in pronunciation. Wednesday, 18 September 1996 MAIN COMMITIEE 4631 Dr Solomon's research showed that it was necessary to produce a reading method which could capitalise on the consistent findings that children learnt to read by breaking up the sounds in words. The 'Reading for sure' program has already been used in a number of Scottish schools, where it was used to train severely dyslexic students to read. Within 18 months of starting the 'Reading for sure' program, most of these students, who had reading skills five years below average for their ages, had caught up to the same reading levels as their peers. I mention this only because, if we raise a generation of people who have only the most basic reading and writing skills or who cannot even count without a calculator, and if we continue to have a generation like this, industry will not be able to advance. According to the same 6 April article in the Economist that I quoted from earlier, a report released in January this year by Industry in Education, a British employers group, said that what they really needed was not more skills training but people who could actually address an envelope. I have spoken to Dr Kemp, the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, about the 'Reading for sure' program, and I will continue to lobby for funding for this and other numeracy and literacy skills programs after the budget, so that we can give our youth-and adults, for that matter-the most basic skills of being able to read, write and do arithmetic, so as to assist them to get jobs that will lead to a better future for themselves and for Australia. I want to point again to the responses I received to the survey I recently sent out to small businesses. They strongly indicate their support for the measures put forth by this government and they particularly agree with our commitment to scrap Labor's unfair dismissal laws, so as to give small business a chance to employ people and to thrive again. As I drive along the Albany Highway in my electorate of Canning and look at the new developments taking place there, I can see that business confidence has grown with the election of the Howard coalition government. Some very large businesses are expanding, promising higher employment and a much healthier local economy. New shopping complexes and factories are being built, whilst others are being enlarged. This confidence augurs well for the future. I have already stated that small business is Australia's largest employer. We need small businesses in our suburbs and our towns, not only to provide local amenities and facilities but also to provide opportunities and work for families. My remarks during this appropriation debate have been mainly concerned with the need for small business to succeed, the need for reducing our country's huge bankcard debt created by the previous Labor government and the need for a stable economy. Indeed, we cannot halve our social problems in this country if we cannot solve our fiscal problems. This budget goes a long way to solving our nation's economic ills. I look forward to Australia reaping the social benefits once our economy is back in shape. Bill (No.1) provides further evidence that the coalition government's policies and philosophy stem not from the homes, the workplaces, the communities or the lives of ordinary Australians but rather that they find their genesis amongst the pages of the driest of economic rationalist textbooks and theories. I have no doubt that is primarily from where the previous speaker, the member for Canning( Mrs Johnston), received her economic education. In the time. I have available today, I would like to highlight some of the ways that this budget impacts on the people of my electorate. Having driven along the Albany Highway this year and noted the similarities between the south-eastern suburbs of Perth in the electorate of
title: Representatives Main Commitfee

speaker: Mr Wilton (Isaacs) (10.48 A.m.)
theText: The budget we are debating today in Appropriation4632 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 18 September 1996 Canning and those of my south-eastern Melbourne electorate, in particular in the area of Cranbourne, I have no doubt that the two electorates would feel the impact of this budget in very similar ways. Cranbourne is the third fastest-growing area in Australia and, like the electorate of Canning, could very much be described as typical of middle Australia. The government would no doubt have us believe that Cranbourne and like suburbs around the country were the beneficiaries of this budget, that it was aimed fairly and squarely at them and that they will, in the government's words, no doubt be better off because of it. It is time that we had a fairly critical look at the glib rhetoric that emanates from the mouths of members of the government, especially in their submissions on this appropriation bill, and to that end I intend to tum to some informed Isaacs local commentary, to see what prospects the budget holds for the people of Cranbourne and, I am sure-by extrapolation-for the people of Canning living on streets that border the Albany Highway. The Cranbourne District Commander of the Salvation Army, Mr Derek Linsell-who, I might add, was a willing host to the then opposition leader, John Howard, on 5 October last year in a detailed tour of the Salvation Army's jobskills facilities in Cranbourne-recently summed up rather succinctly the fear and despair that this budget places on the lives of ordinary Australians, the kind that the government claims to represent. In the 3 September edition of the Cranbourne Sun newspaper, Mr Linsell attacked both the Victorian and federal governments for putting the budget bottom line ahead of the needs of the poor. In that edition of the Cranbourne Sun Mr Linsell said: Ultimately this strategy will come back and bite us on the rear end. We're all going to have to get used to 10 per cent of Australians being in an underclass, which will mean more crime, more vandalism and more poverty. So much, I might add, for the fulfilment of the government's promises to assist the families of middle Australia, as claimed by the honourable member for Canning. Mr Linsell went on to say: My concern is that we just don't seem to care for people. History shows us that this is not only bad economic policy, it is also bad social policy. This is the same man who happily led John Howard by the arm around the Salvation Army facilities in Cranbourne late last year. He went on to describe how the situation in Cranbourne, in middle Australia, is deteriorating. He said: Six or seven people are coming to us every week for emergency housing. That demand has come from nowhere in the past couple of months and some homeless people are living in squats. Cranbourne is all about people achieving the great Australian dream of having a family and owning a house. Many people come here expecting to get on the housing ladder and find they can't. Mr Linsell went on to warn that Cranbourne was facing a welfare crisis which could push many recipients into a permanent underclass. I have no doubt that we can all see worrying signs. We realise that we will always have poor people, to greater or lesser degrees. But the beauty of Australia over the last decade or more has been that we have put a safety net in place. The danger-and this view is shared by Mr Linsell-is that this safety net will simply disappear. I have no doubt that his fears are particularly well-founded. This budget will do nothing for those in our community who are struggling to raise their families, run their businesses and achieve their goals in life. The family tax packages offer little because of the cuts that are being brought to bear, whether they be in the fields of Wednesday, 18 September 1996 MAIN COMMITfEE 4633 education or health. In fact, one of the great urban myths that is developing in this country is that the so-called easing of unfair dismissal laws will be the great panacea for small businesses which have been the beneficiaries of a low inflation and low interest rate economic regime for several years. As the Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Beazley) so precisely put it in his address-in-reply to the budget: The message of this budget is don't be sick; don't be old; don't expect to go to university; if you're unemployed, too bad; and if you're young and unemployed, forget it. I think we should look at some of the impacts of this budget in more detail. I have made some brief mention of cuts to the health portfolio in this budget which targets private hospitals, pensioners and the disadvantaged through a massive reduction in public hospital funding, higher charges for prescriptions and reduced access to dental services. So much for this budget fulfilling the promises, hopes and dreams of middle Australia, as claimed by the member for Canning. The budget papers indicate that a further $320 million has been cut from grants to the states over the next four years. In addition to the sum of $600 million pro rata health reduction announced at the previous conference, this will dramatically increase hospital waiting lists for those who depend on public hospitals. Pensioners will have to pay an extra $100 million a year for drugs under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. The cost of each script will increase to $3.20 without any compensating increase in the pension. In perhaps one of the more pertinent issues, which has been the subject of complaints to my office in recent weeks, the betrayal of the least well off in our society is compounded by the abolition of the Commonwealth dental program. The news that the federal budget will end funding of the highly successful Commonwealth dental health program can only be described as callous and miserable. The Commonwealth dental health program was introduced by the previous Labor government in 1994 to assist the states to reduce severe inequality in dental health care in the Australian community. Under the program, dental health services were available to the holders of pensioner concessions, pensioner health benefits, health care and Commonwealth seniors cards. Some 4,736 health card holders were treated in the electorate of Isaacs alone last year, with nearly 200,000 people across my state of Victoria receiving some form of dental treatment. The providers of the dental care under this program in the electorate of Isaacs include the Berwickwide Community Health Service which provides both general and emergency dental care to residents of Cranbourne, Berwick and Packenham. It treated 1,389 patients from the town of Cranbourne alone last year, as well as the 528 patients it treated in-house. The service also referred 861 cases to private dentists. Similarly, the Frankston Community Health Centre located in the seat of Dunkley provides general and emergency dental care to residents in the Mornington Peninsula and is likely to lose around a half a million dollars due to the budget cuts. It either treated or arranged treatment with private dentists for nearly 6,000 patients from surrounding areas last year. The centre has two dental surgeries and refers any work over its capacity to the approximately 35 locally operating private dentists. The Chelsea Community Health Centre similarly provides general and emergency dental care to residents in the cities of Kingston and Bayside and treated 2,934 patients last year-a 4634 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 18 September 1996 470 per cent increase over the number of patients it treated before federal funding was introduced. As well as those patients it treats in-house, the centre also refers between 70 to 100 cases a month to local private dentists. The Treasurer ( Mr Costello), in his budget speech, justified the abolition of this much loved dental health program by saying: As waiting times for public dental health services have now been reduced, funding for the Commonwealth dental health program will cease. It looks like the funding abolition will see the waiting lists of these centres blowout, far from being reduced in the future, from around 12 months currently to five years or longer, even for basic dental treatment, blowing the Treasurer's illogical and short-sighted premise well and truly out of the water. Patients from Isaacs in need of emergency dental work will be forced to travel into the dental hospital in the city or be forced to pay private dentists to have teeth extracted as the cheapest option available. The abolition of this program will no doubt be a tragedy as it enabled the less fortunate members of our community who previously received only the most basic of dental care or who missed out all together to receive the dental health care that they both need and deserve. As the Leader of the Opposition said, it is hard to think of a more callous budget decision in the last decade or one that more clearly breaks the Prime Minister's commitment not to hurt the most vulnerable in our community. Again, so much for this budget fulfilling the promises of Australian middle-class families as submitted by the member for Canning in her speech in this place not a few moments ago. The security and quality of life of older Australians have also been made much less certain by this year's budget. The decision to force those in need of nursing home care to find the money to pay an up-front entry fee is an attack on people at a very vulnerable and a very fragile stage of their lives. As we all know, this entry fee will be something like $26,000 but could be as high as $88,000. On top of the entry fee, nursing home residents who are not full pensioners will be charged nursing home fees of up to $34 per day, or some $12,000 per year. This fee is charged as soon as a person's income goes $1 above the pension free area. The many older Australians-there are many of them who live in Isaacs-who receive care at home via the home and community care program will be faced with much higher user fees for the first time as a result of this budget. When I returned on the Friday of budget week to my electorate of Isaacs, one of the first functions that I attended on that day was the Longbeach schools district mid-project achievement celebration at the Mordialloc Primary School in the heart of Isaacs. The celebration might have been referred to better as a commemoration rather than a celebration because there was something bitterly ironic in the fact that such a function should take place only days after the federal budget spelt the end for the very program that was being celebrated. The function celebrated work carried out on 22 schools within the Longbeach schools district under the federal governments new work opportunities program--one of the programs claimed by the member for Canning to have fancy names and not much else. The work included the construction of rotundas, pergolas, amphitheatres, brick and concrete paving, outdoor furniture, Wednesday, 18 September 1996 MAIN COMMITIEE 4635 garden beds and general building maintenance at schools within the Longbeach district. To date, approximately 50 per cent of those works have been completed. According to Mr David Turnbull, the project coordinator, participants of this project employed adults who were willing to take the first step on the road to employment. The skill and pride that they have demonstrated in the work they have completed is reflected in the high standard that has been achieved. I can attest to that high standard, having seen many examples of it in and around schools across the electorate. But the government has decided to shut down over the next 15 months every significant locally run job program, such as new work opportunities, which have helped local people gain the skills, expertise and, most importantly, the self-esteem and confidence required to take that all-important first step back into the workplace. Other labour market programs to be abolished include jobskills, skillshare and jobclubs. Again, these are initiatives which have more than just fancy names. These are initiatives which make the less than confident in our society understand that they can go out there and get work if, through these programs, they are job ready. But the coalition government has gone back on its promise not to cut labour market programs which help unemployed people find these real jobs. These common sense programs, such as new work opportunities, have been real success stories, getting people off the dole and providing them with skills and training, which make them attractive to employers. The2 September edition of the Frankston Standard newspaper provides us with yet another example of irony. The Liberal member for Dunkley( Mr Billson) is reported as praising the Mornington Peninsula jobsnet campaign for what he called its 'meteoric rise' in the number of traineeship places available in the Frankston and Momington areas. The honourable member rightly pointed out the importance of traineeships and the success of this particular program, which is a joint effort between local business, media and DEETYA, in getting more than half of the trainees into ongoing real jobs. The irony was provided some two pages later in the same edition of that newspaper in an article entitled 'Jobs scheme future doubt'. The first paragraph of that article states: The Peninsula's successful and much praised job creation campaign, Jobsnet, has been cut adrift by the Federal Government. Cut adrift-despite its worth being recognised by the member for Dunkley and despite receiving glowing praise from the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone, when she visited us in relation to the same scheme only last month. On a budget of $72,000 last financial year, jobsnet created 1,076 extra jobs in that 12 months, with over 280 young people now in permanent work as a result of this program. The Westernport Area Consultative Committee generously donated $15,000 to the program to see it through the coming years-more accurately, to see it through to the end of this year-but its long-tenn prospects are in jeopardy. Given the Howard government's own predictions of little or no reduction in the unemployment rate in the foreseeable future, without effective labour programs such as skillshare, jobsnet and new work opportunities, the unemployed face a very bleak future indeed. I could go on at some length to talk about cuts to legal aid. The pensioner legal aid centre has been the victim of significant cuts to the legal aid budget and no doubt will be devastated by cuts to its budget starting in financial year 1997-98 of over $33 million-more than 20 per 4636 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 18 September 1996 cent of what the Commonwealth spends on legal aid funding. Again, this will impact most savagely on the needy in our society, quite contrary to the submissions by members opposite during this appropriation bill debate. When I was first elected to parliament I made a pledge to the constituents in Isaacs. That pledge was that I would hold this government accountable to meet the high standards set by previous governments and demanded by the people of Australia in ensuring that the principles of equity, of tolerance and of community which underpin our society are the parameters which guide and control our law makers and those whom we charge to enact those laws. Along with my colleagues from the Labor Party who have spoken out against many of the provisions of this budget, I believe we have clearly demonstrated that it falls well short of the standards set by previous governments and that-far from being guided by the principles of equity, tolerance and community-the ideology behind this budget is that of the bottom line, an ideology which recognises the cost of everything but the value of nothing. Ms WORTH (Adelaide) (11.08 a.m.)-It is with pleasure that I rise today to speak in support of the budget measures announced by this government in Appropriation Bill (No.1) 1996-97. This is the first budget of the 38th parliament, and one which takes the first step in turning around the creeping sense of inevitability that was beginning to pervade Australia prior to the 2 March election. No longer must we resign ourselves to a declining. standard of aged care, a shrinking small business sector, apathy about the macro-economic environment and finding real jobs for Australia's long-term and young unemployed. This is a bold budget. Not prepared to put off the tough decisions and be content to tighten spending, this government has reaffirmed its commitment to economic responsibility and to providing Australians with real answers to the dilemmas caused by unemployment, public sector debt and a feeling of isolation within the mainstream in Australia towards the decision makers of this country. This is a firm but fair budget. It is also somewhat of an anticlimax for members on the other side of the House in light of the ridiculous claims that they made before the budget. Unfortunately, the scaremongering and exaggeration about the effects of the budget have continued, as has been so evident by the standard of debate from some of those on the opposite of the House. As the Adelaide Advertiser commented, rarely have Australians been presented with a happier anticlimax. It went on to say that there were actual advantages for families with children and for some couples. Can we forget the scaremongering of 12 per cent cuts to universities, the reduction of the aged care pension and jobsearch allowances and the number of other untruths spread throughout Australia about the unknown content of the budget? As one newspaper announced, this budget is about priorities and pragmatism. It makes a priority of those vast sections of the Australian community forgotten and neglected by Labor and also makes a priority of the reduction in debt and deficit with fairness, with this government asking all sections of the Australian community to contribute. It is pragmatic because it does not avoid the challenge of reducing public sector debt, and it is pragmatic in the sense that it highlights the need for long-term strategies to deal with Australia's chronic unemployment problems. The coalition has delivered, in the context of the economic mess left by Labor, a sound budget. This government, as has been made abundantly clear in this budget, is about fairness and sharing the burden to undo Labor's economic legacy. The 'spend, spend, spend' mentality Wednesday, 18 September 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4637 of Labor has allowed it, like some sugar daddy, to buy its way into Australian political folklore. It irresponsibly increased public spending to feed the ravenous hunger of special interest groups and has pursued a policy of trophy economics, of grand schemes and Keating's so-called 'big picture'. But I put it to members in this Main Committee that the Commonwealth's ability to continue to provide quality services depends upon a reassessment of the level of public expenditure. To do otherwise would prove to be a far greater threat to the provision of quality services than this budget has been made out to be by the Labor Party. Under Labor, Australia's economic sovereignty was placed in a perilous position, with our net foreign liabilities, as a proportion of GDP, the third worse in the industrialised world, ranking Australia 45th out of 49 countries in terms of external debt to exports. The uncontrolled spending spree has come to a very necessary end. The deficit, however, will remain an ever present reality. The government will have to work within the economic confines it has created. In true form, the Labor government, instead of contributing to repairing the economic mess that they created, accuses this government of ideologically driven cuts. If propriety is an ideology, if responsibility to the taxpayer of Australia is an ideology, and if fiscal restraint in light of this economic debt is an ideology, then I and my coalition colleagues stand guilty. I would argue, however, that far from ideology, this is a budget driven by common sense and pragmatism. A 'spend, spend, spend' mentality cannot go on forever unabated and without direction or proper financing. This budget also returns the political momentum of this country back to those who Labor has for so long forgotten and neglected, as is so apparent from the attrition inflicted upon Labor on 2 March. Among their numbers were small businesses everywhere. Labor went into the 1996 election with nothing to offer small business. It is no understatement to say that the coalition has done more for small business in the last six months than Labor did in 13 years. The reduction of the tax uplift factor, changes to capital gains tax arrangements which will amount to a $150 million tax cut, the provision of information, consultation and support mechanisms, a reduction in red tape and better relations with the tax office and, most importantly, the scrapping of Labor's unfair dismissal laws are among the broad vision this government has for restoring some faith in a crucial sector of the Australian economy. As Max Walsh commented, the bottom line is that the budget is good for business and good for Australia. Contrary to the lies circulated during the election and again in the lead-up to budget night, the coalition will continue to index pensions at current rates. What a scandal for the ALP to circulate any information to the contrary to the 14,800 persons on the age pension in my electorate of Adelaide. The government has also eased the burden on self-funded retirees, providing them with the same tax rebate as pensioners. Couples will now have a tax-free joint income threshold of $19,850. In regard to health policy, the government has made up to $250 available to couples and at least $450 available to families to put towards private health insurance. This is a significant step towards undoing the outrageous negligence of private health in this country, which has seen levels of persons covered by private health insurance drop to just 34 per cent. The only way the health crisis can be averted in Australia is by coordinating the recovery of both public and private health sectors. You cannot do that with only one in three people in private health insurance, and Labor never had the answers. 4638 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 18 September 1996 High income earners will face an increased Medicare levy surcharge. That is right and proper. Again, this is a measure aimed at equity and at sharing the responsibilities of Labor's terrible legacy. In addition, there are important improvements to public health. Areas that have received particular attention are the national childhood immunisation program, the national diabetes action plan, maternal and child health, injury prevention, and life education centres. Improvements in rural health include the setting up of a department of rural health in rural areas, with links to university medical schools; the Institution of John Flynn scholarships for medical students to give them greater exposure to country medical practice; and the provision of financial assistance to help improve locum arrangements. This government did not create the unemployment disaster in Australia, but we will take the long-term responsibility and put into place measures that will reduce unemployment. Only a long-term strategy will do justice to the nature and enormity of the unemployment problem in Australia, and the best and most genuine way of creating more employees is to create more employers. I have already spoken of the many benefits to the small business sector, but I would like to add that initiatives like the $207 million apprenticeship scheme and the ongoing reduction of interest rates will improve the macro-economic climate for employers, thus making them more confident about expansion and the increasing of staff numbers. Complemented by the government's intended reforms in the workplace, this is the only way that a long-term recovery in employment figures can come about. These measures reveal the mind-set of the government which is aimed at real solutions, even if the benefits will not be seen overnight. This is in direct contrast with those who are now in opposition who were intent on the bandaid measures and short-term irresponsible strategies which were so convincingly rejected by the Australian public at the last election. For all those people on newstart, for the 3,485 people on jobsearch and for the 178 people on the youth training allowance in Adelaide, this is the first good news they have received for some time. Again, putting some balance back into job training, this government has allocated $3.7 million in the next four years to rebuild the decimated apprenticeship and traineeship system. The budget does not pretend that the problems of long-term and youth unemployment will be solved overnight, but it does provide real hope to our jobless and the end of the cruel and endless training merry-go-round that was the norm under Labor. These budget measures are about real job creation. The allocation of $20 million over two years to the Australian Taxation Office will boost investigation of the tax avoidance schemes of the super-rich. This is simply another fair and equitable measure intended to ensure that all sections of the community contribute to restoring financial security for Australia's future. Much has also been made of the announcements of changes to the higher education portfolio. But let me take this opportunity to remind members that the coalition changes mean that students do not have to pay up-front fees and will not be denied entry because of an inability to pay. They will be required to pay HECS only when they can best afford it as they recoup the financial and career rewards that the study they have undertaken brings to them. The message sent out by the opposition parties in regard to full fee-paying places has been particularly disappointing. Full fee places mean extra places at university over and above those Wednesday, 18 September 1996 MAIN COMMIITEE 4639 that are funded by the Commonwealth. Overseas students have had the opportunity to buy places at Australian universities for years. Under access and equity principles, surely it is only fair that these opportunities be extended to Australian students. The Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone, has stated that the government is firmly committed to maintaining the level of benefits to eligible families which Austudy provides. At the same time, we want to send a strong message to the whole community that well-off families with extensive assets and on high incomes will not be eligible to receive financial assistance via Austudy. Again, an element of fairness has been added to the measures already in place. Not only has the coalition government set about undoing the mess left by Labor, but it has gone as far as possible to ensure that this situation never repeats itself. The charter of budget honesty will ensure that this shameful chapter in Australia's economic history is brought to an end. Let me remind members that last year the previous Labor government spent $10 billion of taxpayers' money to repay interest on government debt, both here and overseas. The public sector debt must be reduced in this country, and the Australian Labor Party should be honest enough to acknowledge this and to acknowledge its own culpability in creating this situation. The previous Labor government taxed and it spent. Labor increased wholesale tax and petrol tax, introduced the FBT, raised the pension age for women to 65, introduced retrospective HECS changes, increased the Medicare levy and raised company tax. Despite this, Labor still managed to accumulate $69 billion in deficits over its last five years. As Terry McCrann has stated: This is the Budget we had to have-and self-evidently never got and never would have got from the previous occupant of the Lodge. Another commentator, Alan Wood, has stated frankly: Labor should apologise for its terrible failure as a financial manager and help Costello clean up the mess. One of the most disastrous examples of Labor's mismanagement was the running into the ground of Australian National, in my own electorate at the Islington workshops and elsewhere around South Australia and Tasmania. In the 13 years, the number of employees of AN has declined from 10,500 to 2,500. Yet Labor now triesMr Sawford interjectingthe opposition attempted to pretend that this had occurred since the change in government. But they do not fool the workers at AN who know and understand the situation. They know that Labor set up National Rail and that AN had, in the words of one worker, 'the guts ripped out of it'. And in the words of another: If the National Rail Corporation was made to pay its way at market rates, Australian National would still have its original investment which it could use to invest in other areas, such as the Alice Springs to Darwin rail link or other investment which would benefit Australian National, the country and, ultimately, the Australian taxpayer.
