speaker: Ms Worth
theText: The member for Port Adelaide tries to lay the blame at our feet.
title: Representatives Main Commiitee

speaker: Mr Sawford
theText: Exactly.
title: Representatives Main Commiitee

speaker: Ms Worth
theText: How wrong he is.
title: Representatives Main Commiitee

speaker: Mr Sawford
theText: Impossible.
title: Representatives Main Commiitee

speaker: Ms Worth
theText: Was he on the government benches in recent years? As recently as yesterday4640 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 18 September 1996 There is some good news in the budget for the workers and their families at the Islington workshops and for the residents of my electorate who live nearby. Money is at last available to clean up the badly contaminated land there, and that was confirmed in the House yesterday by Minister Sharp. All this is in sharp contrast to the previous ministers for transport, Senator Bob Collins and the member for Kingsford-Smith( Mr Brereton), who talked on this subject but never delivered. As the Treasurer ( Mr Costello) has also recently commented: We do not want to condemn Australia (() a high deht future, nor put at risk the reduction in interest rates and the growth that will flow from it. That's the choice. There are no easy choices in relation to the Budget ... If we don't do it now, future generations are going to have less choice than we had because they are not only going to be trying to pay for their own services out of their own taxes, they are going to be servicing the dehts that we ran up on their behalf. I endorse those comments. They encapsulate the position-that bind, if you like-in which the government finds itself. The coalition has introduced some tough measures, but they are for the future for us all, and to guarantee future Commonwealth credibility in financial matters and the Commonwealth's ability to provide quality services into the next century. Labor created this mess and now wants to obstruct the very measures that will undo it. In regard to interest rates and business and consumer confidence, this is an especially irresponsible measure. Under Labor, home mortgage rates hit 17 per cent and business loans went over 20 per cent because Labor could not control its spending. As the Treasury secretary has stated, Australia will be 'courting danger' by doing anything else but putting into place a sincere and genuine attempt tu tackle government debt. I read with some shock the comments by the Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Beazley) to the effect that the budget was an act of betrayal and the first step towards a new, unfair society. I have gone to some lengths to explain the many fair measures in this budget that give no small amount of attention to ensuring that all sections of the community contribute to undoing Labor's mess-the legacy of its betrayal of Australian taxpayers, the unemployed, the elderly and the battlers. In speaking on the budget, I cannot let the events that transpired on the eve of the budget go without comment. I was in the position to observe these events first-hand for one and a half hours as I assisted those who sought to defend this place. Television coverage of the event did much to convey the violence that was apparent that afternoon, but television is a medium that does not easily capture in its entirety the mood that can be present during such an event. I can assure all those who think that the riots were sensationalised or over-reported that the threat was very real and a pervading sense of fear hung heavily on all those who were present in the foyer that afternoon. I would like to take this opportunity to place on the record my admiration for the way the Federal Police handled that situation. They were calm under extreme provocation. Damages arc now estimated at $300,000 and I hope that those responsible are made to pay. I know that there is extensive video film of the riots and some people have already been identified. One unionist from Adelaide, who authorised such charming election material as the message, 'If you believe in religious freedom and human rights, put Worth last,' has been identified as heing a ringleader. In conclusion, I would like to address some of the issues raised during this debate by the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson). I would like to draw all members' attention to the fact that Wednesday, 18 September 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4641 the federal seat of Oxley is one in a desperate position. In many ways, it is a microcosm of Labor's mismanagement. The member for Oxley would do better to address the problems of unemployment and poverty in her electorate than to make overgeneralised attacks on our indigenous communities and bodies like the United Nations. What will negative campaigns do to alleviate the suffering experienced by her constituents? We have seen only this week the benefit of being part of the United Nations, with Australia sponsoring an anti-nuclear testing agreement. This will prove beneficial for all Australians, including the constituents in Oxley. But the member would have us leave it. The member for Oxley refers to her research proving that indigenous Australians are better off than nonindigenous Australians. I have already circulated to my parliamentary colleagues, in July of this year, my own arguments that reveal the shortcomings in her research. All members on both sides of the chamber are here to represent all sections of the Australian community, and to promote the politics of inclusion and tolerance. It achieves little to concentrate only on negatives and those arguments which seek to divide. In particular, I wish to raise the issue of Grayndler and the impact that this budget will have on my electorate. The people in my electorate have been hurt by this budget. They have been hurt because of the savage budget cuts inflicted on them by the new Howard-Costello razor gang. I was at university the last time the coalition handed down a federal budget. At the time, I believed that the then Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, was a Thatcherite. In hindsight, he was positively dripping wet compared with his sidekick, the architect of the first razor gang, the now Prime Minister( Mr Howard). Mr Howard promised during the election campaign that services to people in need would be maintained. He promised stability and he promised fairness. Obviously, these were not core promises, because what this budget delivers is cuts to services and instability for families across the country. budget probably does represent and deliver for people in St Ives, but their interests are not the same as those of the people in Marrickville. Apart from making savage and unnecessary cuts to the public sector, higher education, ATSIC and the ABC, what this budget does is to shave off funds from virtually all government sponsored service delivery programs, which will adversely affect people most in need. Let us look at my electorate. I stated earlier that the people I represent have been hurt by this budget. They are people who can least afford to be hurt. According to the 1991 census, 41.6 per cent of people in Grayndler were born overseas-the Australian average is only 22.3 per cent-and 47.8 per cent of people speak a language other than English at home. The Australian average is 15 per cent. By and large, the working people of Grayndler are wage and salary earners-88.8 per cent. What effect has this coalition budget had on these people? First of all, the Medicare office in Marrickville Road has been earmarked for closure but, never fear, they are going to put a fax machine in the local pharmacy! It is a pity that this cannot be programmed to assist those residents whose first language is not English, and it is a pity that those who cannot afford to
title: Representatives Main Commiitee

speaker: Mr Albanese (Grayndler) (11.27 A.m.)
theText: I wish to speak in opposition to this budget.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Dr Nelson
theText: Rubbish!
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Albanese
theText: I say to the member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson), in particular, that this4642 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 18 September 1996 wait for cheque refunds are going to be disadvantaged by this. I note also that there are no Medicare offices on the hit list to close in the seat of Bennelong or in the seat of Higgins. Secondly, the CES offices are closing. They have been marked off to close at Marrickville, Ashfield and Leichhardt. I guess if you cannot register for work you do not appear in the unemployment statistics. Just a few doors down from my electorate office is Marrickville Skillshare. This is an organisation which has excelled in getting long-term unemployed people into real jobs. On average, 60 per cent of their clients go on to find long-term employment. Furthermore, Marrickville Skillshare has developed a specialist expertise for people from non-English speaking backgrounds. What is their reward for such conspicuous success? The minister responsible, Senator Vanstone, has decimated the Skillshare budget. Its staff numbers have been halved. This time last year Marrickville Skillshare was able to provide six months training and work experience for 45 adults and 42 youths in its brokered programs. Today, the brokered programs no longer operate. It is likely that for this financial year Marrickville Skillshare will be funded to assist 340 clients as opposed to the 800 that it assisted in the last financial year. Labour market programs are the key to addressing the problem of unemployment in this country but all this government can see is the amount of money that can be saved by cutting them down to the bone. Even if you look beyond the rationalist response; even if you look beyond the human cost of unemployment then you will see that the economic cost is also massive because people, if they are not in jobs, are not paying taxation. Therefore, on the revenue side you lose money and on the expenditure side you are forced to continue to pay out social security rather than people gaining their income from employment. This is policy madness. It will lead to an increase in unemployment and it will also have a long-term negative economic effect. Moving a little further afield we come to the Marrickville region Adult Migrant English Service situated at Enmore. This time last year AMES was running 15 DEET funded English for Work courses. These courses are by and large taken by highly motivated, newly arrived migrants. The courses themselves are not for the faint-hearted. There are three levels, each of which involves 20 hours of intensive English tuition over 20 weeks. Upon completion of English for Work III, students would be considered eligible for entry into TAFE vocational courses. How many courses are currently running today at Enmore AMES? There are two! Last year there were 15, now there are two. Forget the shaving analogy of the budget I used earlier, this is slash and bum. Incidentally, AMES also runs adult migrant English program courses for the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs but from 1 October this year the concessional rate of $2,205 for the English education charge will be scrapped, which means that NESB migrants will have to pay the full charge of $4,405. On1 January 1997 the charge will rise to $5,500. Currently, some 90 per cent of people who pay the charge are eligible for the concessional rate. This cost recovery measure inflicts a further financial burden on the very people who can least afford it: new and potential migrants. This is another example of the government implementing an agenda which has played up to the racists in our community, which suggests that those in ethnic communities can go to the bottom of the pile. Perhaps when we see the Prime Minister show some leadership in speaking out against people such as Pauline Hanson Wednesday, 18 September 1996 MAIN COMMITIEE 4643 he will have some credibility and the people on the other side of the table will have some credibility as well. Realistically, the only migrant groups unaffected by this charge, the only ones that have been left alone, are those from English speaking countries. There is a lot of rhetoric also from those on the other side about the family. Increases in child-care fees are inevitable given the loss of operational subsidies for community based long day care centres. Families using these centres will be paying around $20 a week more for each child in care. My electorate has 16 community based long day care centres providing places for 756 children. This provides the opportunity for the parents of those 756 children to actively participate in the labour market and provides 252 workers at these centres with employment. All this productivity comes at a cost of only $820,275 in operational funding to the government. This is peanuts, given the productive value that these parents have for our economy. Community based child care aims to provide affordable, quality care. The prime motive for private child-care centres is making a profit. Therefore, it is community based child care that sets the standard in the marketplace. This represents yet another broken promise by the new government. In a letter to the Australian Early Childhood Association, dated 28 February 1996, just days before the election, the then shadow spokesman for family services, Dr David Kemp, made a commitment to preserving the operational subsidies, and I quote: The policy also states our continuing support for the community-based long day care sector, and we regard the operational subsidy as one of the key supports of that sector. The coalition has no plans whatever to change the operational subsidy. It is a very clear commitment that has been broken by those opposite. I guess this is just another one of those non-core promises. We had two sorts of promises. There were the ones that the new government kept. They were the core ones. All the rest were the non-core promises. They do not really count. We will remember that and we will be reminding those opposite of it in the lead-up to the next election. The so-called family-friendly tax initiative is also fundamentally flawed. A low income family who, by necessity, must have both parents working gets a tax break of only $1,000 per dependent child. Such a family may earn only $70,000 a year, or $35,000 each. However, a single income family can earn up to $65,000-which increases by $3,000 for each additional child-and get the $1,000 per child and an additional tax break of $2,500 if they have a child under five years. Therefore, a family with three young children, struggling on a combined income of $60,000 a year, gets a $3,000 increase in the tax-free threshold. However, a single income family with three young children can earn $71,000 a year and get the $3,000 plus an additional $2,500 increase in the tax-free threshold. The message is very clear. To women in middle-class families, who can afford that, it is: stay at home. But to those on the lower end of the rung it is: bad luck. There is no equity in this decision. Let us face it: the only people this family tax initiative will assist is upper middle income earners who can afford to live on one income. Low income families, who by necessity must have both parents working, are, in effect, punished. These tax concessions, along with the cuts to the child-care sector, are a transparent attempt to get women out of the work force. Women being forced to leave the work force provides a double bonus for the government. Firstly, their departure creates a job vacancy and, secondly, because they cannot afford to be in the work force, they do not register for work and therefore 4644 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 18 September 1996 do not appear in the unemployment statistics. Is this the coalition's secret strategy for bringing unemployment numbers down? Certainly, this budget is not making Australia the clever Gountry. Another area where the people of Grayndler will be hurting is in changes to the higher education contribution scheme and Austudy. Understandably, most families are very keen to see their children succeed. This sentiment is especially strong in first-generation Australian families, who by and large had very humble beginnings. I remind members that almost half the population of Grayndler was born overseas. One form of relief for these parents was that independent Austudy became available to many students at the age of 21. To raise this to 25 years places an untenable burden on many families. Furthermore, lowering the income threshold for HECS repayments from $28,495 to $20,701 means that many graduates will find it very difficult to get ahead. As a result, they may need to rely upon the support of their parents even longer. The likely outcome of these changes is that children from lower income families will be forced to give up the dream of a tertiary education because their parents simply cannot afford it. But then, perhaps this is actually one of the aims of these changes. I can assure the Main Committee that, contrary to comments made by Senator Vanstone, not too many students from the inner west of Sydney will be paying their way into university in the 'dumb but rich' category that is being implemented by this government. The privatisation and Americanisation of the Australian higher education system, whereby people from richer areas, from rich families, can buy their way into university, having not got the marks, is a disgrace-given, in particular, that they will have had advantages of going to the sorts of upper-class private schools that some of the people opposite obviously went to. The elderly and the frail are not immune from the new, improved razor gang either. There is nothing like hitting people when they are down. The coalition government has withdrawn $88 million from its contribution to home and community care funding. And the government's proposed solution of the shortfall in funds? User pays, of course-user fees for meals on wheels, user fees for home visits, user fees for community transport, user fees for respite care, user fees for shopping support, user fees for home maintenance. These services allow the elderly and the disabled to remain in their homes with dignity. Without them they will be forced into nursing home care. But of course they cannot really do that, because once they apply to get into a nursing home, having had the choice of staying at home taken away from them, the government begins to impose an up-front fee of an average of $26,000. This may not be a lot of money for people in Bradfield, but I can assure you that it is a lot for people in Grayndler and it is a prohibitive amount for vast numbers of elderly Australians and their families. Furthermore, thanks to the budget, people already living in nursing homes face increased fees. This will negatively affect almost 2,000 elderly people currently living in the 34 nursing homes in Grayndler. There are 1,954 people in my electorate who will be impacted by this. Perhaps one of the most unjust aspects of this government's cost-cutting plans is the threat to the Commonwealth-state housing agreement. Funding for the next financial year may remain stable, but it is only while reforms are being worked out. It is clear, however, that these so called reforms will lead to funding cuts of up to $500 million. The importance of public housing may be lost on the coalition government, but for hundreds of thousands of people across the country it is no exaggeration to say that it is a lifeline. Having grown up in public housing for the first 20 years of my life, I certainly can attest to that. -" ',',I',',,',' Wednesday, 18 September 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4645 The government's idea, in effect, is to abolish public and community housing, and to extend rent assistance to public and community housing tenants. In an area like the inner west of Sydney, the rental market is very tight and market rents are very high. You would be lucky to rent a bed-sitter for less than $100 a week and an average three-bedroom home would rarely be leased for less than $300 a week. Such a change would alter the whole character of inner city areas, where public housing has ensured that there is a mix of people of different backgrounds. Even with increased rental assistance, low income families will be severely disadvantaged by the loss of public and community housing. The effect of these changes is potentially devastating to low income families. But then it seems clear to me that when the Prime Minister and the Treasurer talk about family friendly initiatives they do not include lower income families. In conclusion, this budget will increase inequality. It is a road which has been gone down before; it is a road which Margaret Thatcher went down in Britain, and Reagan and Bush went down in the United States. But it is a road which is being rejected all over the world. The UNDP's Human Development Report, which came out this week, when comparing economies throughout the world said: ... the key to East Asia's success was a relatively equal distribution of private and public assets. Countries there concentrate on redistributing not income but wealth. What generates income is productive wealth. A progressive redistribution of assets tends to boost growth because it has a broad positive effect on people's incentives. There is also a report by the OECD that came out in July 1996. This report concluded that growing inequality is far from conducive to growth. It admits the future prosperity of OECD countries depends on reducing social and economic exclusion in the forms of high unemployment, non-participation in the labour market and, in some instances, growing inequalities in earnings and incomes. The World Bank has also put out a report suggesting that growing inequality is bad for economic growth. I would suggest that the results of this budget are very much going to be a reduction in economic growth, an increase in unemployment and an increase in inequality in our society. When you look at the labour market programs, where you have a strategy implemented to have labour market programs withdrawn, you also have changes to the social security system with massive proposed increases in penalties for people. If you do not turn up to a job interview, you can cop up to at least 13 weeks withdrawn social security payments. Some of the honourable members around this House should think about what they would do without 13 weeks of any payment. Those people have to get their money from somewhere. This is not a 'fair go' budget as the government would like us to believe. It is a 'have a go' budget. Have a go at the elderly. Have a go at the unemployed. Have a go at low income families. Have a go at women. Have a go at students. And have a go at people least able to fight back. I urge the House to reject the measures in this budget. Dr NELSON (Bradfield) (11.47 a.m.)-BeforeI commence I would have to refute some of the nonsense that was just said by the honourable member for Grayndler ( Mr Albanese). The best study on income distribution in Australia was done by Boyd Hunter and Bob Gregory from the Australian National University. Bob Gregory was a member of the Reserve Bank Board. From 1978 to 1991 the top five per cent of income earners in this country increased their average income by 23 per cent. The bottom five per cent reduced their average income by 22 per cent and, in fact, the people who were displaced most from the work force were 4646 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 18 September 1996 women in low socioeconomic areas and blue-collar workers. This budget, amongst other things, actually does a great deal to try and reduce income disparity in Australia. In the period leading up to the March federal election I was asked by a number of people why I was in such a hurry. I replied that this election was occurring at a time when, in every sense, our country was at a turning point in its history. As such, I do not consider that the election was a cricket match to which we would return in three years time, nor was it a question of whether John Howard or Paul Keating would occupy the Lodge for the ensuing three years, but rather, the outcome of the election would see the economic and cultural destiny of Australia set for the next 30 years. This budget represents the first of what will be a series of major changes in direction for Australia. In its broader sense, it heralds two fundamental shifts in the way that we see ourselves. The first is to set a three-year program to tum the deficit into surplus to stop indulging the present generation at the expense of our children. In returning expenditure to a level below that of income and consolidating this nation's capital base, we begin the long road back to funding social infrastructure from income rather than from the accumulation of further debt in the sale of assets including the acquisition of Australian companies by foreign interests. The second major change and arguably the greater change to be found in the budget papers is a cultural shift. Under the previous government, in particular, the expectation of what governments can and will provide had grown at an unsustainable rate. This budget represents the first instalment on rediscovering the forgotten ethic of those who can afford it being encouraged, if not expected, to care for themselves, whether that be in health, aged care or higher education. The opposition parties, and the Labor Party in particular, cannot seem to make up their minds. On the one hand, the shadow Treasurer, suffering from relevance deprivation syndrome, certainly publicly, and I suspect also within the Labor Party, agrees to a three-year strategy for deficit reduction, but on the other, thinks that $7.2 billion in savings should be obstructed. As Alan Wood, in the Australian on September 10, said, Labor seems intent 'on extending its record of fiscal irresponsibility into opposition, aided and abetted by the Australian Democrats. ' For every billion dollars of budget savings blocked by the opposition, another billion dollars has to be raised on the international equity markets or through the sale of Australian assets. In debating this budget, this parliament needs to put our circumstances into proper perspective. We have had external deficits in 28 of the last 30 budgets. Sixty-nine billion dollars was accumulated in deficits by the previous government's last five budgets. Household savings at 2.5 per cent of disposable income are the lowest in the OECD and the lowest savings ratio in the developed world. We have a lack of savings, public and private, which has meant that growth approaching 3Y2 to four per cent has required us to use monetary policy and increase interest rates to stop a balance of payments problem, with people who are left trying to manufacture in Australia having to borrow money offshore in order to support growth. The use of our debt under the previous government to prop up consumption has exposed us to an exchange rate depreciation. Four per cent of our gross domestic product has been spent servicing debt and equity obligations. Net foreign debt approached 40 per cent of GOP and, under the previous government, debt reached a staggering 19 per cent of gross domestic product. If you then look at Eslake' s work on social security payments, he found that, in 1970, Wednesday, 18 September 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4647 18 per cent of Australians over the age of 15 were in receipt of some kind of social security payment. In 1995, 30 per cent of the people in this country over the age of 15 were in receipt of social security payments, and if you excluded unemployment benefits it was 24 per cent. Last year we spent more on health, welfare and education than all of the money raised by taxes on income-and that is PA YE taxes paid by the attendants in this chamber and by people in blue-collar areas, like that of the member for Grayndler ( Mr Albanese) and the member for Port Adelaide( Mr Sawford), who are out there working today. I repeat: more money was spent on those three big-ticket items than all of the money raised on taxes from income. The amount spent last year on health, education and welfare was $71.3 billion. In contrast, $65 billion was raised by taxes on PAYE income earners. You cannot have it both ways. You cannot snuggle into bed with two to three per cent underlying growth, denying transport, communications and industrial relations reform on the one hand, and then, on the other, insist on free education, health and aged care. The Labor Party's history of opposition to serious tax reform completes a picture of disengaged unpreparedness for the realities this nation now faces. Little wonder the shadow Treasurer's accurate self-diagnosis of relevancy deprivation syndrome! Let's hope it is not contagious-for the member for Port Adelaide at least. This budget finally moves Australia in the right direction. In the 1995-96 budget, the deficit, as we now know, was $10.5 billion. That is 2.1 per cent of GOP. cent of GOP. in the following year we will return to a surplus of just under $1 billion. What the member for Port Adelaide fails to appreciate is that in those other countries that have those levels of debt they also have high levels of growth, they have high levels of savings and they also have positive balance of payments. What this means to us, to everyday Australians, is a return to surplus, an effective long term improvement to national savings and to a deep-seated balance of payments problem and, along with industrial relations reform, unshackling of the impediments to growth. The other important aspect of the budget that needs emphasis is a charter of budget honesty. For the benefit of members on the other side, honesty means that you actually tell the truth, that you tell people what the facts are. The charter of budget honesty requires that the heads of the Department of Finance and Treasury will sign off on an economic and fiscal outlook within 10 days of the election being called. After the election is announced, the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition can request costings of their announced policies by heads of the Departments of the Treasury and Finance. It requires annual updates on the government financial position and economic outlook. Every five years the government will have to publish an intergenerational report which assesses long term sustainability of its policies. It will require a fiscal strategy statement to be produced annually and, of course, we will move to accrual accounting. When asked to specifically rank 12 listed national issues in order of greatest importance to them, 11.4 per cent of respondents nominated foreign debt as the highest priority; 10.9 per cent, taxation reform; and 10.3 per cent, health care financing reform. But analysis of the responses showed that there was a significant proportion of residents who consideredcorrectly, in my opinion-foreign debt, taxation reform, interest rates and unemployment to be issues where both the problem and the solution were interdependent. I should also point out to the House that, whilst a code of ethics for parliamentarians rated a 12, a significant number of respondents explained that, although they were placing it last, in their opinion the ethical and professional behaviour of federal parliamentarians would be likely to substantially improve when the then Prime Minister finished his term. Question4 invited respondents to nominate the single most important issue that I should address on their behalf, and 265 respondents rated economic productivity issues as the highest priority to them, followed by health, social services, social justice and youth unemployment. I also advise the House that, in analysing the more specific responses to this question, I was struck by the concerns shown by Bradfield residents not only for the economic indices, but also for a higher priority to be placed on what might be loosely described as social justice issues. Amongst these, permeating the survey was a concern for Aboriginal reconciliation, foreign aid, community service and the treatment of carers, the despair of young people, and what could be described as the compassionate manifestations of the elected government. Some of the calls that I have received in my office in the last few months have related, in fact, as much to those sorts of issues as they have to economic ones. The most interesting part of the survey was the specific comments that people made. I have 160 pages of comments in my electorate office. theText: The survey was distributed to the households in my electorate and requiredWednesday, 18 September 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4651 responses, because I believe that they confirm that, in a general sense, the budget is moving in the direction in which my constituents would like to see us go. The following are quotes from my own constituents. 'I feel powerless as I see Australia slipping downhill.' ' ... working for the good of Australia and Australians on a long-term basis rather than on an ad hoc basis geared to the next general election.' 'Population growth: do we need to grow? Can we sustain growth?' 'The question that needs to be asked is: does Australia need multiculturalism? We are not being asked; we are being told that it is good for us. I question that.' 'I have been disillusioned with the political process and its participants, short-term perspectives and constant criticism of the opposition, irrespective of what is good for the country.' 'No private enterprise could exist if managed the way this country has been in the last 20 years. Change it and make decisions.' Other responses included the following. 'Develop and rediscover hope in people's lives. Give incentives so that effort is rewarded and they can achieve their dreams.' 'We desperately need support for small business: simplification of rules governing small business to encourage employment, and simpler tax for casual or part-time workers. There are too many rules and regulations covering the simple exercise of doing a day's work.' 'Unless we rectify economic issues first, the nation cannot afford to rectify quality of life issues' -and therein lies the fundamental difference between us and the opposition party. 'Let's get the country back on a sound financial footing first. You cannot have quality of life in a sick economy.' The responses continued: 'The issue I rank above all those listed is the increasingly inequitable income distribution in Australia, such that the rich are getting richer and the poor are becoming more numerous and poorer. We face a bleak future if this trend is not reversed.' 'There should be a long-term bipartisan plan for Australia, not three years stumbling from election to election.' 'An economically strong Australia will benefit all its citizens.' 'We are living beyond our means. We must cut spending under our present government.' 'Introduce a GST-we are currently taxing all the things we are trying to encourage.' 'The plight of our Aborigines is a national disgrace. It is embarrassing that so many Aboriginal people do not even have access to basic needs.' 'Has Australia really become an Asian country? Where are we heading? Are we acceptable to the rest of Asia? How must our people change?' 'Industrial relations: there must be a proper balance between capital and labour. Each must cooperate with the other and bloody-mindedness exists on both sides. Our national future depends on cooperating effort.' 'Make unemployed people work for the dole, for example helping in nursing homes, gardening for the aged and other community programs.' Further responses included: 'The problems facing self-funded retirees are becoming overwhelming. We are treated almost with contempt. We urgently need tax relief, support with private health insurance and concessions available to government funded pensioners. Why is it that you work all your available years and are taxed, try to save and you are taxed, then retire because you have made an effort to save, do not get a pension and still get taxed?' 'We have the tragedy of family break-up due to the ease with which the young can obtain support from the government, and we parents are told that it is none of our business when we appeal for help. Amongst numerous families I know in this predicament, my own daughter left home at 15 years. She was at a private school-paid by us-but still managed to get Austudy on two occasions when stopped by us. In the three years away she has managed to live on welfare, jobsearch allowance, workers compensation--obtained after one week's work-and other handouts which she wastes on trivialities, including cigarettes and alcohol. 4652 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 18 September 1996 A group of them move from place to place and therefore do not pay any rent. It annoys us immensely that this child earns more than I do a week, as I work part time, have eight certificates and a degree. My husband is too busy trying to survive in business to tell you what he thinks. Do the best you can.' The responses continued: 'The only way anyone will employ young people is if there is a youth wage.' 'I wish to live in a just society with equal opportunities for all. It may surprise you that I do not mind paying taxes to bring this about.' 'What a welcome relief for someone to ask my opinion.' 'The total negativity of one political party to the other is appalling. The TV picture of abuse and name-calling is so pathetic and we refuse to watch it. See if you can bring some decency and respect back into federal politics.' 'The country has no hope, the way things are going.' 'If you are going to pursue politics do it with passion and not platitudes. Make the tough decisions and not the politically expedient.' The responses included also: 'Youth suicide: concentrate on the needs and welfare of our young men and women, particularly, and give them hope.' 'Please oppose republicanism. We believe this overrides all the above mentioned issues.' That was a comment from a household of eight people aged 9 to 89. The next respondent said, 'The republic: I will not vote Liberal because of the attitude to a republic. Liberal policy has to broaden its appeal.' So on it goes. These are people in my electorate expressing their own concerns, their own aspirations for Australia, and this was at a time immediately prior to the election. It was a time when we were labouring, if you like, under the previous government. Therein lie many of the reasons why there was a change of government and the reasons why the people wanted to see change. I know that the member for Watson( Mr Leo McLeay) yesterday described me as 'the silvertail doctor'-I wish I were a silvertail-'from the Upper North Shore of Sydney'. But the aspirations and concerns of the people in my electorate are in many ways little different from those of the people in Grayndler or in Port Adelaide. They were desperately concerned about the way our country was going, and they really felt that, while there were many decent people in the previous government, the government in almost every sense had lost its way. To refute the idea that everyone that I represent is wealthy and affluent: I will never live in a three-storey mansion, I will never own a Rolls Royce, but I will fight to the death for the right of any Australian, whether they live in Grayndler, or Bradfield, to believe that one day they might be able to do that. The budget is about those two things, as I said earlier. It is also about us stopping indulging ourselves. Of course, in many cases we would love to fund not only the things the opposition is concerned about but also much more; but we can only spend what we earn. Every time we spend more than we are earning, we are spending the future savings of our children, we are forcing people in the private sector to borrow money from overseas, and we are continuing the pressure to continually sell Australian assets. On this issue, by the way, of the electorate that I am privileged to represent, one respondent said to me, 'Remember that there is an underclass on the North Shore and that we are hidden, but we are trying to live with dignity on social welfare.' I am very much aware of that fact. I commend the budget to the House. It is going to do two things. It will return us to the position we were in pre-Whitlam, which is that our social infrastructure will be funded on income rather than on debt. It will, as I said before the election, also change the destiny of this country. We now have a Prime Minister who is like anyone of us, an ordinary man, a Wednesday, 18 September 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4653 man who clearly is relating the decisions that he and the government make to the concerns and aspirations of people in my electorate and people in the electorate of Grayndler and of Port Adelaide. He is someone who is obviously taking into account what we think when he makes a decision on our behalf. Those of us who are privileged to be members of this government will do everything that we can to see that the voices of our constituents are being heard, whether we happen to agree with them or not. I commend the budget to the House. path of the downsizing of government involvement in the economy that has been at the heart of economic thinking in this country for more than a decade. However, this government has taken the credo a step further in what I believe are its misguided endeavours to balance the budget inside of two years. Let it not be forgotten: the so-called $10 billion Beazley black hole is about one-third of the Howard cosmic catastrophe left in 1983, yet that was brought back into balance, as indeed can this deficit be controlled more conservatively, and with less disruption, than this budget allows. In the desperate rush to win credit ratings from the money markets, we have slashed any meaningful commitment to many of the long-term unemployed and to regional development, Aboriginal reconciliation, alternative energy development, and our national broadcaster. We have premised any environment commitment upon the sale of our greatest earning asset; which sale will provide, for the huge environment problems we face, less funding than has been provided in normal outlays in forward estimates in recent years. Middle Australia has been provided with a tax break, on the one hand, but has been asked, on the other hand, to fork out more for child care; while dental programs for the disadvantaged and elderly have been dismantled. First, let us examine the labour market programs. New employment placement enterprises will now be paid on the basis of their success in getting unemployed job seekers into sustained employment. While this new market driven labour program is attractive to free marketeers, the payment structure will, according to the budget papers, 'be focussed on finding people jobs rather than placing them in training programs.' What a wonderful motherhood statement! Will this mean that the displaced power workers, the road workers, and the defence factory workers of the Lithgow district, for example, will be delivered into new jobs? Where, I ask, will these new jobs come from? The government has set no target on reducing unemployment, and most indications are that it will sit at around eight or nine per cent for the foreseeable future. So where, I ask-as we downsize Telstra even further by 23,000 jobs, as we become even more efficient for the sake of fewer and fewer-are these jobs that these entrepreneurs of the unemployment marketplace are to deliver? PEPEs, those private employment enterprise centres, look set to be the boom growth industry of the late 1990s. For what results? At a time when there are few jobs emerging in regional Australia, our government has chosen to slash back its commitment to regional development-surely the catalyst for growth and job generation. To expect a balanced budget to deliver lower interest rates and then, by some magic, a growth in job investment, is pure fantasy. The transport and regional development sector of these budget papers is shameful. Apart from a commitment to maintain a bipartisan agreement on the Pacific Highway funding, nearly every category is a negative. That is a cut in regional commitment. Let me list just three of them: a $132 million reduction over four years in funding for the national rail infrastructure authority; a massive reduction in funding for the national highway system; and abolition of the regional development program which has been

speaker: Mr Andren (Calare) (12.07 P.m.)
theText: The 1996 budget represents a continuation down the4654 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 18 September 1996 severely criticised by local government, farming, commercial and community groups around Australia. At a time when regional Australia is crying out for infrastructure assistance, this government is turning its back. When the minister announced the RDOs were being cut, I said I looked forward to his commitment of projects of 'real and lasting benefit to regional Australia.' Where are they? A political handout of $48 million has been provided, in such excruciatingly tight fiscal times, to the South Australian Liberal government for Adelaide airport. Let us analyse this. Given that Adelaide airport's performance is declining, how does this government find $48 million to extend what is one of the country's lowest ranked airports-being neither a major tourist destination nor having any significance as a freight airport-to link into south-east or north Asia? Adelaide is primarily a domestic airport. In the financial year 1995-96 it handled just 230,000 international passengers-just two per cent of the national total-while at 6,554 tonnes of airfreight exports in calendar year 1995 it barely exceeded three per cent of the national total. Yet this government has found $28 million this year, and a further $20 million next year, to fund Adelaide airport runway extensions. At a time when we need to be funding-and when both sides of politics promised-at least a feasibility study of a new freight airport at Parkes, this government has provided zero, zilch, nothing, to a project that potentially could deliver many hundreds of jobs and billions of export dollars from goods delivered efficiently to our markets to the north. It is difficult to see what benefits will flow to Australia from $48 million worth of Adelaide airport extensions--certainly not a huge leap in international passenger traffic or airfreight export from an airport ranked below Cairns in importance. This budget has also sold out any real commitment to alternative energy research. The fledgling ethanol fuel industry, of which the Manildra group was a major player until budget night, has rightly challenged statements by energy minister Senator Parer who claims, 'current production and use of fuel ethanol is not cost effective in reducing emissions of greenhouse gas and environmental pollutants.' The axing of the bounty, due to be in place until the year 2000, saved the government $21 million. That bounty has helped attract more than $40 million in private sector investment in viable production of fuel ethanol through the processing of feedstocks. The ethanol bounty scheme also provided $4 million for research and development of processes to produce ethanol from forest plantation thinnings, sawdust, crop stubble, cotton trash and biomass from urban waste, among others. That research and that 18c a litre bounty have been stopped dead in their tracks. Along with the government's refusal to endorse the greenhouse emission targets that the rest of the developed world demand, this decision displays a lack of environmental concern, policy that suits the petroleum industry, and a guarantee that if our economic direction may no longer be that of a banana republic-although I have doubts about that-our environmental record is certainly heading that way. Since World War II, government subsidies to the oil industry are estimated to be $2.9 billion. Against this is the $25 million under the ethanol bounty scheme, $3.9 million in associated research and development, and $2 million for a pilot ethanol program. Yet the Australian Institute of Petroleum complained that the bounty would give ethanol an unfair advantage. Major oil companies refuse to participate in the bounty scheme, but 100 independently owned Wednesday, 18 September 1996 MAIN COMMIITEE 4655 service stations have been supplying ethanol blend fuel in Sydney and regional areas. The dark shadow of the oil giants lies right across this disgraceful budget decision. Such also are the environmental credentials of a government that wants to flog off our most valuable asset on the spurious grounds of setting up an environmental heritage trust, which could easily be funded by accessing that very Telstra dividend indefinitely. The Telstra sale is not about the environment; it is a continuation of the shameful disposal of our national assets begun by that champion of national sovereignty, Paul Keating, and embraced with passion by the Liberal Party. The National Party has tagged along with this economic lunacy, too timid to argue against, and now enmeshed in the sticky web of, downsizing and sell-offs to explain to its bewildered and angry constituency why government and former government services and publicly owned enterprises are disappearing before their eyes. To dispose of Telstra, delivering $2.3 billion to its shareholders-the people of Australia-is short-sighted economic vandalism. Let us tum to the elderly and how they may be treated by this budget. The changes to nursing home contributory funding-the shift of costs from government to the public-must be better explained to an older generation that has yet to be fully consulted about the implications for the family home, the inheritance that all older people want to hand on to their children. Such cashing-up of assets to pay for nursing home accommodation also dramatically underlines the physical cut these elderly people must make from the life outside to that within an institution. Chances are that many families may choose to try and keep their frail elderly in their homes and try to provide less than professional caring. I hope there is no plan here to ease the demand for nursing home beds. The Thatcher government introduced a similar scheme-the cost was debited to the elderly patient's estate-that brought about a huge increase in home care, with disastrous social results, but delivering the desired cost shift from the government to the patient or their family. But having said that, I must report that one local community body in my electorate, the Yeoval Multipurpose Health Centre, containing as it does a nursing home, hostel and hospital, sees real benefits in obtaining such funding from local clients to enable maintenance and extensions and improving a facility for the benefit of local elderly people, who will, in fact, be investing in a community asset, ensuring its continued viability and caring for older people within their own district, rather than their being forced to seek nursing accommodation in some more distant town. This is perhaps one of the unintended and unsuspected positive outcomes of this new policy for more remote towns and communities. But it certainly needs widespread explanation and consultation before it is implemented, because there is a concerned sector of the elderly population in larger centres, such as Orange, Bathurst and Lithgow, who see this is an assets grab for little apparent return. Having paid taxes in the past to support aged care, they are now being asked to pay for their own. Mr Deputy Speaker, while mentioning the Yeoval Multipurpose Health Centre, might I plead with the government to research this model of what smaller centre health care should be all about and to maintain federal commitment to the multipurpose centre biannual grant program. The Yeoval community have been successfully conducting their multipurpose health centre for seven years, and they firmly believe the concept is one that suits rural and remote areas. So do 1. 4656 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 18 September 1996 Throughout my electorate there is grave concern at the abolition of the dental health program, to save this government $55 million alone over the next 12 months and $112 million, $114 million and $116 miIIion in each of the three years after that. The Minister for Health (Dr Wooldridge) said in the House that it was a very difficult decision, but cuts had to be made. He said that it was a program that had handled the backlog and was now to cease. Why, then, was there no money set aside for the years ahead? Do underprivileged and elderly people's teeth stop rotting now that the backlog has been met? In the Orange, Cowra, Lithgow and Bathurst health districts, there is a six-month waiting list for people to access the program. That was before the budget. Emergency care only is being offered from now on. Over 20 per cent of the population will now be denied this assistance; 74 per cent of dental health funds for the economically deprived have gone; four clinics in the region will close. It is a service for which there is no substitute except a dramatic decline in dental health care for disadvantaged young, adult and aged. The Commonwealth sought, and gained by referendum in 1946, the power to make laws for the provision of 'hospital benefits, medical and dental services'. In his policy launch of 18 February this year, the Prime Minister vowed to 'continue an effective social security net for the disadvantaged and needy and to maintain all current Commonwealth concessions' which includes dental concessions. Half a million people access this scheme. If it is discontinued there will be waiting lists three years long by 1998 and after that these people will be forced to have their teeth extracted. The state cannot pick up the huge funding shortfall to deliver these services. Changes to the higher education contribution scheme could also impact heavily on my electorate and rural Australians. While I have no great problem with a modest incremental increase in the contribution to tertiary education by its beneficiaries, the steepness of these increases will particularly hit remote and distance education students from institutes like the Orange Agricultural College. The cost of $4,800 or thereabouts for rural science and marketing degrees will prove too expensive for many rural students coming from somewhat depressed areas in the bush, trying to upgrade their skills in a rapidly increasing competitive agricultural marketplace. I have fears, too, that the dramatically increased HECS will tum many economically disadvantaged away from tertiary training generally, and their skills could be lost to the nation. I applaud the extension of the actual means test on Austudy to catch those rorting the system through manipulation of their taxable incomes. It is a patently unfair system which excludes many deserving students with honest parents while including children of families that have prodigious wealth. Why can't part of the savings in the higher education area be directed into more Commonwealth scholarships for the lower income groups, complete with living away from home allowances-a scheme that worked so well in the 1950s and 1960s and offered a transparently fair income tested access to university for thousands of young Australians? One thousand such scholarships for rural and remote area students is a start, but it must be multiplied twentyfold and offered to students right across the spectrum. Those who can pay should assist more; those who cannot must be assisted in far greater numbers than this budget provides. Otherwise, we will fail to tap the intellectual resources of young people trapped by the economic circumstances of their parents. The cutbacks to Aboriginal funding-the ATSIC slashes-have been well documented. This country has debated Aboriginal welfare for decades. We have patronised indigenous Wednesday, 18 September 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4657 Australians for generations and only in the last decade has any semblance of self-determination, apart from Wave Hill, emerged. Yet, at the start of so-called reconciliation with the first Australians, we have buckled to impatience, ignorance and mischief at best, racism and deliberate community division at worse. We have pulled $400 million from Aboriginal programs. It is one thing to share the budget pain, it is another to devalue both funding and self-determination. Our spending on Aboriginal programs-$1.5 billion out of $130 billion-is about 1.2 per cent of total outlays, less than the two per cent of the population that Aborigines represent. Let us get this funding priority in perspective. While the extension of SBS to more regional areas is welcome, the 10 per cent cuts to the ABC in each of three financial years from 1997-98 and the current thrust to further corporatise this great broadcaster represents an assault on our cultural infrastructure unrivalled in recent times. I search with hope in these budget papers for a sign of real commitment to regional Australia. I applaud the supermarket to Asia strategy to boost food exports, but I despair at the lack of commitment to any infrastructure designed to get food to those markets. I heard the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy( Mr Anderson) say: It is a carefully designed strategy to identify bottlenecks. I suggest that air freight transport-an exclusive air freight component and an exclusive air freight industry-is an obvious one needing direct support now and not another committee. I applaud the $115 million funding boost to CSIRO. I applaud retention of the diesel rebate scheme provided that its rorts are attended to. I applaud exceptional drought circumstance funding continuing and rural adjustment funding. They are vital and obviously welcome. I applaud the fringe benefits tax exemptions and the capital gains rollover concessions-a boost to small business that will hopefully be supplemented by amendments to the unfair dismissal laws. I was pleased to see a $36 million road black spot funding program until I saw the $621 million cut in national highways spending over the next four budgets. A throwaway line on page 158 of the budget statements says: Funding for national highways has been reduced. Well, $621 million is a devastating reduction in a country crying out for better roads as our arteries are hammered by heavy road freight that should be on rail. Sydney-Melbourne rail freight, for example, has dropped from 50 per cent in 1972 to 20 per cent now. The green corps job scheme is welcome but will soak up but a minute fraction of the LEAP and other former labour market unemployed scheme participants who will not qualify for traineeships-perhaps 60 per cent of our unemployed. A one-stop employment and social security service will be achieved through closure of CES offices in many areas with resulting net loss of jobs. The MAATS system of apprenticeship and traineeships is very welcome. But the cost of implementing it will be at the expense of programs for the most desperate unemployed. It seems that the gold medallists of the jobless market will be catered for but the long-term unemployed will languish, too difficult to train, not potentially productive enough to attract the new bounty hunters of the labour market. 4658 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 18 September 1996 Medicare services will allegedly be improved by closing Medicare offices and asking chemists to take over this complex task complete with fax machines and 1-800 lines for the old, the ill and the confused. In essence, this budget begins to balance the books. But it is too rigorous. In so doing, it creates an imbalance in our society that may well prove counterproductive, socially divisive and uneconomic, particularly for regional Australia. At a time when we need vision and renewed commitment to publicly funded soft and hard infrastructure this budget takes it away. At a time when we need to support job generation in regional Australia this budget does very little. Australians expect a mix of public and private ownership and investment; a mix of private and public employment. By reducing its own spending so severely and relying on the market place to fill the void, by expecting struggling users to pay more by shifting costs to the states, this government and this budget risk contracting the economy of regional Australia even more. 1996-97 on behalf of the people of McEwen; those families who have battled to make ends meet; the young people denied access to higher education or a job; the farmers who have survived drought and flood, volatile commodity prices and high production costs while competing in global markets; and small business people who have survived high interest rates, mounting compliance costs, unfair dismissal laws within a rigid labour market system and a tax system that actually penalised them for working hard and building up their businesses. I speak on behalf of all of these people who, for the first time in more than a decade, have an opportunity to break free from the legacy of disadvantage and dishonesty that has held them back and denied them opportunity. They know that we are entering a new era. This has been recognised by editorial comment throughout the country and is reflected in comments, like those of Terry McCrann, describing the budget as 'arguably, the only honest budget in living memory'. People realise that as a government we have not tried to hide the facts. We have stated right up front what the real problem is-a huge deficit of $10.3 billion with a rising level of debt, including a rapidly rising level of Commonwealth government debt moving over the past six years from $17 billion to $96 billion, an increase of 464 per cent, as a result of policies introduced by the previous government. The major task facing this government is to reduce that deficit and level of debt in the fairest possible way by providing measures to sustain growth and enable business to begin to thrive, while ensuring that those in real need in our communities are cared for. In order to achieve that, a substantial program of reform is needed. That is exactly what the Treasurer ( Mr Costello) has delivered in the first budget of the Howard government-a program of reform to reduce the rising levels of deficit and debt. As the Treasurer said, although we did not create these problems, we have taken the responsibility of fixing them. This will be achieved largely through expenditure savings, some reduction in tax expenditure, and a crackdown on tax avoidance. The hard decisions needed to begin the repair and reform of our economy are long overdue. People in my electorate are appreciative of the fact that this government is prepared to take strong measures but will do so in a way that is fair, balanced and responsible. There are no increases in income tax rates or company tax rates, nor are there any increases in wholesale tax or petrol excise. This budget offers hope and a revitalised future for our country.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mrs Bailey (Mcewen) (12.27 P.m.)
theText: I speak today on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1)Wednesday, 18 September 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4659 One of the key areas this budget will address is the enormous problem of unemployment that we currently have as a direct result of both monetary and fiscal policies pursued by the previous Keating government. The facts about levels of unemployment are these: throughout the 13 years of Labor government, unemployment reached levels that we have not seen since the Great Depression of the 1930s. Much is being said by opposition members of late about unemployment targets. I am staggered that these people have the audacity to talk about numbers. Let us put these claims under closer scrutiny. Even though those levels of unemployment were high, they were not the true figure. We know that anyone who worked for a few hours a week was not counted as unemployed, and there were many thousands of people underemployed-working way below their level of qualification or getting only part-time employment and no opportunity to start a career. On top of this, thousands of people were shunted from one training program to another, the only outcome being placement in yet another training program, but no job. The opposition constantly refers to their Working Nation program as a success, but the reality is contained in a DEETYA report commissioned by the former government. This report found that Working Nation failed to assist the short-term unemployed, that it neglected the newly long-term unemployed, and above all, it found that labour market assistance had been changed from inexpensive programs with good outcomes to expensive programs with poor outcomes. It is the height of hypocrisy for these people, who were responsible for such failed programs, to criticise our government-after only months in office-for the unemployment levels that they created. It is also hypocritical for the opposition now to be demanding targets for unemployment, when even the now Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Beazley) said in 1993: Our commitment, as a government and as a nation, should not be any arbitrary unemployment number or rate. Our commitment must be to the reduction of unemployment as rapidly and as completely as possible. The Leader of the Opposition knows in his heart that setting targets for unemployment is not the main responsibility of government; it is to actually tackle the causes of unemployment. The opposition's claim that they could have achieved an unemployment rate of five per cent by the turn of the century is a fairy tale. Setting targets does not create jobs. The reality of the situation is-the people of McEwen recognised this on 2 March-that Labor's policies over the past 13 years have been the cause of unemployment, not the cure for it. Let us examine how the previous government destroyed people's chances of employment. They used monetary policy to create such a depressed economy, where small business-{)ur major employer group--battled high interest rates and lack of consumer confidence. We saw record numbers of business bankruptcies. Those who managed to survive those conditions then had to contend with unfair dismissal laws which resulted in thousands of small businesses ending up in court. An unfair provisional tax uplift factor, high compliance costs and a mountain of paperwork all restricted the ability of small business to become more competitive, more productive and more profitable-the very ingredients needed for growth and jobs. This budget removes those impediments. An amount of $180 million will be delivered back to provisional taxpayers because this government has already honoured its commitment to reduce this uplift factor of six per cent. This means that we have ended Labor's unfair practice of assessing small business for provisional tax on an income in excess of what they have earned. We have introduced 4660 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 18 September 1996 legislation to end the unfair dismissal laws of the previous government. Small business will once again begin to employ people because they will not be penalised for doing so. The impact of capital gains tax in small business has been a serious issue for a very long time. The previous government had the Beddall report on small business for six years but did nothing. That report recommended major changes to tax-including capital gains tax--on small business, but it sat and gathered dust. Once again, this government has demonstrated its commitment to small business by introducing in this budget changes to capital gains tax, allowing profit to be rolled over in order to encourage small business to become bigger. It also allows those small business people-who have risked their capital, worked hard, supported themselves, provided employment for others and used their business both to provide a livelihood for themselves during their working life and to build up a nest egg for their retirement-to be exempt from capital gains tax up to a capital gain of $500,000. This budget also provides encouragement for employee shares as a form of savings through more generous tax treatment. All of these measures are designed to get government off the back and out of the pocket of small business and allow them to thrive in a, more flexible economic and labour market environment. The Australian electorate must be aware that the very people who, when in government, sat and did nothing to help small business employ more people are the same people who, in opposition, are crying crocodile tears about unemployment levels while preparing to vote against our measures of reform in this budget. In other words, they did precious little themselves while in 13 years of government and have now set a course of action to prevent this government from making the changes that they failed to make. We were elected to tackle this problem. People said that they had had enough of being told that this was as good as it gets, when all around they were confronted with the reality. In country towns and suburban shopping centres there were vacant shops that had previously supported a family and provided local employment, factories forced to reduce shift numbers, and farms that could no longer afford to employ. There was a massive shift from productivity to dependency as the CES list grew and numbers of social security recipients grew. That is what this government inherited after 13 years of Labor government. Those in opposition, the very people responsible for that legacy, are now the ones opposing and criticising aspects of reform that we want to introduce to fix the mess they created. They lack all credibility. However, we will not be deterred. People elected us to implement reform, and this budget is the beginning of the repair process. This budget marks a turning point for both young and old Australians; for families, for small business in the country and in the cities. Thirty per cent of young people who drop out of school before year 12 have had no option in the past other than to join an unemployment queue. We will change that. This budget makes provision for $187 million for the development of vocational education in schools. This means that young people not suited to, or who do not want to, study at the tertiary level will now be able to begin an apprenticeship at school and get a chance of a career and a job. The Australian Secondary Principals' Association has welcome this initiative by saying: At long last there is a recognition that vocational education is important to secondary schools and has a crucial place in the secondary curriculum. Wednesday, 18 September 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4661 Towards the end of the Keating government, the number of young people in apprenticeships had fallen to the lowest level as a proportion of the work force since the 1960s. This budget sets to repair this situation by appropriating $200 million over the next four years to modernise the apprenticeship system. There are new growth industries like information technology crying out for a highly skilled work force. By providing the funding and making the system more flexible to allow young people to work at multiple sites through group training means that we are providing a modem apprenticeship training system in tune not just with the 1990s but the next century. This gives hope and opens new pathways for young people. This budget focuses on providing the best results through traineeships, apprenticeships and encouraging businesses to take on employees by providing wage subsidies. This budget, Mr Deputy Speaker, also acknowledges the struggle so many families have had in making ends meet over the past decade by providing assistance to approximately 2 million low and middle income families. Eligible parents will receive an increase of $1,000 to the tax-free threshold. This means that a single income family with two children, with one under five, will receive an extra $34 a fortnight. This government has also honoured our election commitment to make private health insurance more affordable to low and middle income families by introducing in this budget a program of incentive payments. From1 July next year eligible families with dependent children will be entitled to receive an incentive of up to $450 per year paid either as an upfront reduction in their premiums or as a tax rebate. These two initiatives mean that eligible families with two dependent children who take out private health insurance will benefit by up to $51.90 a fortnight. We have developed a comprehensive strengthening family strategy to help prevent and overcome family breakdowns. This strategy incorporates measures to support families in times of financial, social and emotional crisis, strengthen relationships and help prevent child abuse, youth suicide and youth homelessness. Mr Deputy Speaker, families living in regional areas have undoubtedly been the hardest hit by the previous government--even to the extent of many of the farming families in the Seymour district of my electorate being denied access to drought relief. At a recent meeting of farming families from this region they readily acknowledged that they could do little to affect global commodity prices. What they want and have been trying to achieve throughout the Labor years of government is a reduction to their costs of production and to be able to operate in a more flexible labour market. They are sick to death of having to watch their products-which have been produced using the most cost-effective means available to themleave the farm gate and lose their competitive edge through the high costs of transport and fuel, and then face delays and further high costs on wharves due to inefficient work practices. This budget recognises the importance of regional areas to our national economy and recognises the hardships and special needs of people living in these regions by providing extra assistance for education, health, child care, landcare and road funding. The Prime Minister's announcement of the supermarket to Asia strategy is a tremendous boost to regional Australia. This not only recognises the advantage we have as wellrespected producers of clean, green produce from a disease-free environment and our proximity to the Asian markets, but acknowledges the role regional Australia will play in the future MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 18 September 1996 , development of value-added products to an Asian food market estimated to be worth several hundred billions of dollars over the next decade. This future development, however, and the jobs that will be created in the process are dependent on us as a nation being able to harness our natural resources, talent and technology to take advantage of prospective markets. This budget underpins our future success in these areas. Yet again we find an opposition ready to put this development at risk by opposing aspects of this budget. The extension of the export market development grants for the tourist industry demonstrates a clear commitment by this government to encourage further development of this growing industry and highlights the inadequate response of the previous government to support this growth industry. Already there are tourist operators in my electorate eager to take advantage of this assistance and I can assure members of the opposition that they are watching very closely to see how they vote on this legislation. I mentioned earlier the advantages Australia has in producing clean, green food-and how important this is to us as a trading nation. We have this reputation because of our clean environment. However, in order to maintain that reputation as weJl as repair degraded areas, improve our water quality and control weeds and feral animals so that we can increase our levels of production and maintain our marketing edge, we must spend money on restoration of the environment. This budget makes provision for an additional $158 million over the next four years. But this is in addition to the $1 billion Natural Heritage Trust from the one-third privatisation of Telstra. Landcare groups in my electorate are already identifying areas in urgent need of repair that will benefit from this. There is $49 million to assist the states in expediting regional forest assessments in order to fulfil our commitment to implement the national forest policy statement. The central highlands of McEwen will benefit from this process. Once the NFPS is implemented, we will at long last have achieved a balance between protection of high conservation value areas and security for our timber industry, which in my area alone contributes almost $20 million to our national economy and over 600 jobs in the local area. Young people between the ages of 17 to 20 throughout McEwen will have the opportunity to participate in Green Corps and demonstrate their support for preserving and maintaining the environment in a very practical way while gaining valuable work experience. It is imperative that this budget be passed as soon as possible to enable us to begin the job of repairing our nation and restoring opportunity to all. I guess it is not hard to realise why we have been left with such a huge task of repair when the opposition is still not able to face the cold hard facts. Just a few days ago the immediate past Treasurer made some statements that defied all credibility when he said: Clearly, by the standards of comparable countries we do not have a budgetary problem, and we do not have a government debt problem. One can only wonder what sort of planet the members of the opposition are occupying. What it does say, however, is that they are continuing to delude themselves, but at the expense of people in my electorate. This budget is an honest start to begin the long haul of reducing crippling levels of deficit and debt, and restoring confidence. Any attempt by opposition or minor parties to block aspects of this budget -laces this process at risk. (Time expired) Wednesday, 18 September 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4663 to canvass a number of areas in the budget that relate directly to science and research and development, because I think they are quite critical areas and it is very important that we should highlight what the government has done in this budget to these vital areas of our national infrastructure. Unfortunately, as a society we are inclined to take science a little bit for granted these days. Those members who are of my generation will recall that the first lunar landings merited almost a full day of television coverage. There was blanket coverage by the news media of the day, and most of the population was transfixed by the spectacle and gave it a great deal of their attention. Now, I am afraid, this kind of event rates but a few minutes on national television. Indeed, often these things are not covered at all in the United States or in this country because they no longer attract an audience share of comparable size. This says a lot about the way in which our societies regard science, how they regard innovation and technological change. We live in an era of information overload. I am afraid the advances now come so quickly that the public are almost overcome by the rapidity of that change in the science and technology areas and are no longer able to differentiate it, to attune to it, in a way that they once did when the interval between progress and change was somewhat greater.
