theText: The survey goes on to say:Wednesday, 18 September 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4685 imports are up. Senior Treasury officials played down hopes of a rapid improvement in employment from the Government's labour market reforms. And, of course, the other thing that we are regaled with in the budget is the Budget Paper's waxing lyrical about all these problems which will be solved by the government's workplace reform bill. All you have got to do is force the wages down, give the workers low-paid jobs, and that will solve all the problems of the world. SoI was very pleased to see that Professor Gregory was reported in the Financial Review today challenging this very simplistic notion that those on the other side always love to handcuff themselves t-namely, that we will solve all the problems of the world by just pushing down the workers' wages. The Financial Review article, which is headlined 'Gregory challenges Government push on labour flexibility', says: ... Professor Bob Gregory has issued a sweeping new challenge to Federal Government claims that greater labour market flexibility will significantly reduce unemployment in Australia. Professor Gregory argues ... that Government moves toward creating a more US-style labour market will reduce the wages of low-paid workers. The restoration of full employment will lie in a direction other than reducing the wages of the low paid,' he says. The article continues: Noting the Government's claim that its planned individual employment contracts will not worsen employment terms and conditions, Professor Gregory says: 'Is it possible to reduce unemployment and produce jobs by creating greater labour market flexibility, but ensure that this flexibility does not extend to reducing wages and conditions?' So Professor Gregory scotches the simplistic notion that coalition members have always trotted out in this place that all one has to do is crush the workers' wages and the problems of the world will be solved. (Time expired) Ms GAMBARO (Petrie) (5.26 p.m.)-I am pleased to have the opportunity to address the Main Committee on Appropriation Bill (No.1). It is quite interesting listening to the member for Perth( Mr Stephen Smith), who gave us a bit of an economics lesson today. But what is quite extraordinary is that some time ago he worked for the former Prime Minister in the 4686 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 18 September 1996 Treasurer's department. He quoted so many figures of economic growth, but debt level was not mentioned once. He did not reveal that we had the highest interest rates under the previous Labor government and somehow he tried to link unemployment rates with the new incoming government. It was quite interesting that he did not once speak of the debt levels that he left this country with. It was extraordinary that under the previous government we had high economic growth but we have also had high levels of unemployment. I might put to you that the reason that people are not employing-and every person that I speak to will not employ people-is that we need to sort out the industrial relations area. Until that legislation goes through that is the disincentive, not the economics figures and statistics that you quoted. The first budget hrought down by the Treasurer ( Mr Costello) is based on fair and responsible economic management. It is an accumulation of many hours of hard work, and many industry, business and community groups around Australia, and in particular in my electorate of Petrie, have shown their appreciation by applauding the budget. The appropriation bills are Australia's litmus test for the next three years. From the federal election six months ago, this government, the first coalition government in 13 years, has a mandate to return this country to strong economic management. This government has taken the responsibility to bring the $10 billion deficit back to level terms in three years, to throw out the ALP's unfair dismissal laws, to privatise one-third of Telstra, to get small business back working and to provide for the heart and soul of this country, which is families. This government has a mandate because under Labor interest rates were at record high levels, unemployment reached levels not seen since the Great Depression and national youth unemployment soared to well over 20 per cent. As a new member of the House of Representatives representing the seat of Petrie in the northern suburbs of Brisbane, I eagerly awaited the first coalition budget in 13 years. There was a lot of pre-budget speculation around. There were the opposition calls of a horror budget and scaremongering among many groups in the community. My electorate office was ready for that Wednesday following the budget, and were we inundated with budget negativity? No, no, no. My constituents instead were calling me bitterly complaining about the riots at Parliament House and disgusted at the burning of the symbol of Australia, our flag: an episode which I would like all members in this particular chamber to thoroughly condemn. People calling my office were more concerned about the welfare of myself and my staff and offered their assistance, and I thank all those people who contacted my office for their consideration and thoughts. The Petrie electorate includes people from all walks of life: small business, schools, older residents, the fishing industry and local government. Each stands to gain from this budget. As I talk to people in the electorate, I feel that this is a budget for families, for young people in our community, a budget for small business. In fact, it is a tremendous boost to get this country working again. Families are the life and soul of our community. It is the family unit, no matter what shape or size, that is the cornerstone of society. It is families who have found it so incredibly tough over the last 13 years. Double figure unemployment rates, high youth unemployment and high interest rates have left families wondering where the next dollar is going to come from. There are many families out there who are just living from week to week with the bare minimum in their shopping trolleys. This government will provide assistance through family tax Wednesday, 18 September 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4687 initiatives and by providing financial incentives to low and middle income families who invest in private health insurance. This government came into power on the platform of giving hope, of giving respite to families who have struggled particularly hard over the last five years. In the government's first budget, we have delivered. As promised, Medicare has been retained in its entirety and the operational subsidy for family day care centres has been retained, as has child-care assistance and the child-care cash rebate. The government has provided a fair and responsible budget; a budget which will help the hip-pocket of the people of Australia and will give confidence to the marketplace and encourage consumer spending and self-esteem. From my electorate's perspective, one of the most pleasing aspects of the budget has been its flow-on effects for young people. The Howard government believes young people have for far too long been neglected, with sky-rocketing unemployment, spiralling suicide rates, and a lack of hope and inspiration. This cannot continue. Our young people, next year's generation, need hope and inspiration, and our budget delivers. Working Nation has failed a lot of those young people and the long-term unemployed. For too long these people have been going through the revolving door of endless labour market training programs before returning to the unemployment lines. Real jobs did not eventuate, and many of these people lost hope. Confidence in the system plummeted. In workplace reforms, the move towards a quality apprenticeship system for young people has been very well received in the community. Many people can remember the days when apprenticeships led to real jobs. You cannot beat the experience gained from working on the job, and skill based training lays the foundation for a quality system. The apprenticeship system that we have instigated reflects the modern labour market and the needs of business and industry; provides world-class training in skills that business and industry require; gives employers a key role in determining the kinds of skills and training required; and also makes training arrangements simpler and far more flexible. The apprenticeship system put forward by this government is a step towards growth and employment options. The changes proposed in this government's industrial relations mandate will allow for flexible training arrangements. It gives more options and opportunities through small and medium sized businesses, so important to the economic vitality of the Petrie electorate. These changes, importantly, will allow businessmen in my electorate-such as cabinet-makers, fibreglass moulders, mechanics, printers, typesetters and electricians-to expand their businesses, using the talent and skills of the young as apprentices in an affordable and well-managed system. The apprenticeship scheme proposed by this government needs to be cultivated and supported, and can in time bring tremendous benefits to this country. I also wish to support the government's move to curb the high levels of youth homelessness. Organisations such as the Society of St Vincent de Paul, Lifeline, the Smith Family, City Missions, the Salvation Army and those individuals who spend their life comforting those on the street must be applauded. These people have hearts of gold and high levels of determination and dedication, and most of them work in a voluntary capacity in very trying circumstances. The growth of homelessness in our communities is debilitating and does nothing for the self-esteem of families or communities. In a recent edition of the Queensland Courier-Mail, I was saddened to read that the Council to Homeless Persons has warned that Queensland's rate of homelessness was 'nearly twice the national average'. The article reported that it had been estimated that there were some 4688 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 18 September 1996 61,000 homeless people in Australia, of which homeless families make up 13 per cent. Community groups are taking more and more responsibility each and every day, and people are crying out for comfort, support and someone to talk to. It has been estimated that there are over 20,000 homeless young people aged between 12 and 18. This figure is a very sad indictment of our society, and something needs to be done. The youth homelessness pilot program shows the government's commitment to this important area of society. With an $8 million package over three years, it will focus on family relations. The strategy is based on improving the existing supports available and reviewing the ways that information is transferred from community groups to income support agencies. Early intervention and family reconciliation are other areas which are being supported. The fact that the program is voluntary is also important. Similarly, youth suicide is an issue that has touched many families. Australia's suicide rate is one of the highest in the world and this government is prepared to take a stand here. Research and early intervention measures are needed. Counselling services are in great demand and the national youth suicide strategy will be welcomed in many communities, including those in my electorate. While on the topic of young people in our society, I attended a function recently at Deception Bay High School, where the principal, Mr Jim Stephens, was so proud of the achievements, academically, socially and culturally, of his students. Furthermore, Redcliffe State High School deserves special mention with their recent result in the Queensland Rock Eisteddfod, where they finished second-a great result for the determination and dedication of students, teachers and parents. Last Saturday, I was delighted to join the principal of that school, Mr Barry Ferris, in opening up their new performing arts complex, where the Commonwealth invested substantial funding. This government continues to support schools and education in such a way to further improve the opportunities that are available. This budget will provide further incentives for students through educational and training schemes. Over the next four years, Australia's schools will receive $14 billion in funding from the federal government. We are preparing our young people for future employment. In fact, just recently the Australian Secondary School Principals' President, Duncan Stalker, has applaUded the fact that schools are to be given direct access to funding to support an increased emphasis on vocational education for the nation's secondary schools. He said: At long last there is recognition that vocational education is important to secondary schools and has a crucial role in the secondary curriculum. The challenge facing secondary schools is to design and implement vocational courses that are equally valued along with other school programs by students and parents. The Petrie electorate has welcomed this government's commitment to the job placement, employment and training program. JPET aims to assist young people to establish a stable lifestyle, resolve family conflicts, attain life skills, return to education and prepare for entry to and continuing participation in the work force. I commend the funding of $11 million per year over the next two years which has been set aside for this program. We just cannot forget our young. This government has a rock solid commitment to young people in the Petrie electorate and throughout Australia. A key area in getting this country back working again is small business. The Attorney General only this week released provisional bankruptcy statistics, and it is a disgraceful legacy from the Labor administration. There were over 17,000 bankruptcies for 1995-96 and in my Wednesday, 18 September 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4689 state of Queensland, as the member for Brisbane( Mr Bevis) would know, there was a rise of nearly 40 per cent for the financial year. The previous government failed to deliver real industrial relations reform and the current account went out of control, forcing up this country's national debt. I have spoken previously of the sad sight in my electorate of the growing number of small businesses shutting their doors over the last few years. Vacant shopfronts have become a far too familiar sight in too many suburbs, in community shopping villages and even in the central shopping malls. Capital gains tax initiatives introduced by this budget have been very well received in my electorate and the capital gains rollover relief will, in time, have a very positive benefit for many small businesses. They have the opportunity to expand and to create more jobs. Generous tax treatment for employee share schemes will provide a sense of ownership in our big businesses and encourage participation from within. The government has made a commitment to ensure that a lack of financial operations does not constrain growth and development of small business. Business leaders representing prominent Australian organisations recently met in Canberra and they have given full support to these budget measures. They called on the minor parties in the Senate to pass the workplace reforms and, as National Farmers Federation President Donald McGauchie said, 'We expect the passage of the bill to produce conditions for increased employment and higher wages.' Business will be given a choice in managing their work force and enterprise agreements negotiated under a dual system will provide business with much more flexibility than they presently have with a rigid awards system. The key area on the mind of every small business person in my electorate is the unfair dismissal scheme. This is an ALP legacy that will stick to the opposition for many years to come. The present unfair dismissal laws are a noose around the head of many small businesses who struggle from week to week. I am talking about the family corner store, the florist, the baker, the butcher, the coffee shop owners and the restaurants-each and everyone has grave concerns about these unfair dismissal laws and they are crying out for help. What has happened is that the move towards casual work has been the death of many full time jobs. In some industries, where there have been large turnovers of staff, employers have become very careful with their placements. A coffee shop owner in my electorate recently told me that he no longer employs full-time employees, preferring instead part-time and casual workers. This government intends to amend this legislation for benefits across the whole country. Mr Deputy Speaker, this is a further measure which is targeted towards jobs-real jobs-for the benefit of our community. This government recognises the needs of the unemployed, particularly those in the 50 to 60 age group. Many of these people find it terribly difficult to re-enter the work force, through lack of skills or limited opportunities. Whether their predicament is brought about by retrenchment, economic circumstance or family situationmale or female-it is important that the needs of these people be further examined. On the subject of industry, the fishing industry is a valuable asset to the electorate of Petrie. I represented the interests of the constituents with fishing enterprises recently, to save the diesel fuel rebate scheme from abolishment. I am pleased that the diesel fuel rebate scheme has remained intact. This is of particular significance and will achieve economic sustainability throughout the whole fishing industry. Not enough emphasis is placed on the fishing industry. At the moment, many in the industry who harvest prawns are in a state of decline due to poor 4690 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 18 September 1996 climatic conditions. I look forward to working with local and state fishing organisations, processors and consumers, to work towards a more productive sector. I had the pleasure in Brisbane recently, on behalf of the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer), of launching the new strategic plan for the Fisheries Research and Development Corporation-a corporation which has been doing commendable work in managing fisheries research and development programs. Research by the Southern Fisheries Centre, coordinated by the Queensland Department of Primary Industries at Deception Bay, has received funding from the government for its projects, particularly in the prawn trawl fisheries. It is budgeted that the Fisheries Research and Development Corporation will invest $ 13.5 million in 200 new and continuing projects, highlighting the government's commitment to this important resource sector. Mr Deputy Speaker, the higher education sector is of interest to my constituents. I believe the move by the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) to announce budget initiatives early was a positive step to help universities and students in their decision making processes and planning. The Petrie electorate includes the Carseldine campus of the Queensland University of Technology, a university that I have had an association with over a number of years, both as a student and as a tutor. I was very pleased to see that the Queensland University of Technology's operating grants for 1996-97 have risen by 3.8 per cent and the variation for 1996-98 is 4.9 per cent. I expect that the university will benefit from the research funding that has also been made available. The increased funding for university research is upwards of $140 million over four years. The changes to the user-pays system for university education will make it, I believe, a fairer system. The three-tiered system will change for the better the irregularity that existed before. The new proposals are a far more equitable system, streamlining the process which existed where everyone was charged the same, regardless of which course they undertook. Australian students will also be given the opportunity to purchase an undergraduate place, in the same way that overseas students can do now. The reality is that education costs money. We live in a user-pays society, and the variations to the HECS system will provide far more equity. Mr Deputy Speaker, there is a chronic shortage of carers in our community. I have made the point of speaking to many community groups, such as St Catherine's Respite Centre-a St Vincent de Paul centre in the Petrie electorate. The centre caters for approximately 40 clients a day, providing a freshly cooked three-course meal for lunch in a very caring and supportive environment. I have spoken to a number of church and community groups concerning this issue. Respite centres in the Petrie electorate, unfortunately, are limited. There is certainly a great need for overnight centres and occasional weekend care. Those who spend their lives comforting and supporting others must be applauded for their wonderful efforts. If these dedicated people were not so committed, the situation would be far worse than it is today. I will do everything I can to support the needs of carers in my electorate. I will work towards this cause in providing overnight care and weekend occasional care. This is a quality of life issue, and everybody deserves a break to settle their own nerves and their own system. The lifelong love and dedication which carers provide need to be rewarded. The national carers action plan introduced by this government is a step towards this quality of life. This plan recognises the role that carers play, and their importance in today's society. I understand that there will be a focus on matching services and assistance to the needs and circumstances of individual carers. I am proud to see that this government has not ignored Wednesday, 18 September 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4691 these carers and that we have taken them under our wing and will recognise and support their efforts. The importance of this budget will not only have benefits for this country fiscally, but will also provide substantial benefits to the confidence of the business community and families. This budget will lay a foundation for this country's future and provide a far brighter future for all. for Petrie, and I acknowledge her interest and the interest of the member for McMillan( Mr Broadbent) in the small business sector. I look forward to working with them on the inquiry into fair trading and I hope that we can bring in a report that the government will implement. The first budget of the Howard government, presented by the Treasurer Peter Costello, shows once more a lack of imagination from the conservative side of Australia politics in public policy making. In a short space of time, the Treasurer has already shown that he is clearly a slave to economic orthodoxy. There has to be a better way to build a better country than is shown in this budget. The fixation with budget deficits and ultra low inflation rates belies the fact that we need economic growth in which to create jobs. The Howard government has clearly failed to recognise that the role of government is not just to balance the books like a small suburban accounting firm; it is actually to create the climate for economic growth and to redress market failures. Obviously, there have been significant market failures in Australia over the past 50 years. We have failed to address the need to replace jobs lost with new jobs for ordinary Australians. In my electorate of Rankin there is a well known suburb called Inala, a suburb in which I grew up. When I was growing up, there were a number of opportunities for people to work. These included the heavy engineering firm at Rocklea, Evans Deakin Engineering, General Motors Holden at Acacia Ridge, and the Huttons Meatworks. All have since closed due to competitive pressure or rationalisation. What this government needs to do is to tum economic policy into an instrument for creating jobs for these people. The unemployment in this suburb and in other areas in my electorate is unacceptable. It is one of the reasons we are now in opposition. However, the unemployment minister Senator Vanstone has admitted that unemployment will stay at 8 per cent until the year 2000. This is simply not good enough. From their own words the government has let down the unemployed in my electorate and across the country. Let us take a look at what they think the answer is. But let us first say what the answer is not. The answer is not to smash the job schemes that actually help people find jobs, nor to cut $1.8 billion over four years out of labour market programs. I challenge government members to visit places like the Inala South-West Skillshare office in my electorate and to speak with the 730 people who benefited from the Skillshare program during the last financial year. What are these people, and the hundreds of other people in my electorate who found jobs through the Skillshare programs, to do? The government's answer is to cut funding for programs like the new enterprise incentive scheme-NElS-and the jobskill program. These schemes have been successful in my electorate in areas such as Inala, Browns Plains and Woodridge. The answer is not to make the unemployed feel ashamed of their position and guilty by introducing things like the so called 'dole diary'.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Beddall (Rankin) (5.46 P.m.)
theText: It is a pleasure to follow my colleague the member4692 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 18 September 1996 As I talk to community groups in my electorate, I find one thing is certain. Senior citizens are concerned about and just plain scared of the consequences of this budget. The government's decision to align the nursing home system with the hostel system results in senior citizens having to pay an entry contribution to gain admittance to a nursing home. Older members of the community who need nursing homes may have to pay up-front fees of around $26,000. We cannot yet get the Minister for Family Services( Mrs Moylan) to identify what the figure will be. She answers every other question, but will not answer this one. The Minister of Family Services has tried to defend the decision by saying that it is simply a matter of aligning the two systems of nursing and hostel care. This is a ridiculous argument, and it is clear that she does not understand her own policy. You do not need to go through a test to get into a hostel as a matter of choice. You have to be assessed before you get into a nursing home and that is a fundamental difference. It is the reason that the previous government did not relate the two together. Anyone who has any understanding of aged care policy knows that the two types of care are indeed vastly different. The increase in the pharmaceutical benefits scheme will result in pensioners now paying an additional 50c per prescription, or $3.20 in total. Many of the pensioners I represent are angry that there was no warning of this sudden increase. There is not the compensation that there initially was when the scheme was introduced. Many of my constituents who are on fixed incomes will find it difficult to deal with this sudden increase. For a sick pensioner it can mean up to an additional $5 per week. Elderly people who live at home and who have chosen to stay at home in familiar surroundings will be slugged user-pays fees at a rate of around $4 per hour. The government has also reduced its contribution to home and community care funding by $88 million over four years. All these measures make it difficult for pensioners, and they are right to ask why this government is hitting them so hard. Too often we have become slaves, however, to economic theory. That applies to all sections of the Australian political spectrum. What we have to do is find Australian solutions for Australian problems. I recently listened to a debate on the ABC about what used to be called the 'fair go country'. In fact, we have lost in recent years the attitude of a fair go for all. I think the election of this government is a further step away from it. Unless this government recommits itself to the philosophy of a fair go, we will end up as a society with a distinct underclass. I know this because I have seen many of the people in my electorate suffer under the types of programs that have been cut in this budget. What the budget will mean for low income families, pensioners and the unemployed is not a pretty picture. Many members have spoken of how the scrapping of funding for the Commonwealth dental scheme will affect the community. I did some research and found out how many people in my electorate used this scheme, and I was simply staggered by the result. My electorate of Rankin had one of the highest usages of the scheme in Queensland. Over 13,000 residents in my electorate used the scheme during the last financial year. Over 7,000 residents and health care card holders in Logan City in my electorate used the scheme last year. So these people can now expect long queues and much pain from John Howard's broken promises. Before this scheme was introduced, the cost of dental health care was out of the question for many poorer Australians. Under Labor, they were able to receive dental health care. This, cruelly, will no longer be the case. This is an absolute disgrace, and I will be making it clear to the people of Rankin that they have been forgotten by this government. Wednesday, 18 September 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4693 The only way for people to break out of the poverty cycle is through economic development and through jobs. Both of these objectives have not been met by this government in its first budget. Small and medium sized enterprises can offer many opportunities for Australians, as many speakers on the other side have said in their contributions to this debate. Going back a little in time, the McKinsey report entitled Born global, which was brought down in 1993-1 recommend it to all honourable members-showed how many Australian companies are able to focus on new markets, and the global market is part of their initial business plan. This is something that has not been part of Australian culture in the past and something the government needs to nurture. It is not natural for Australian companies to think of international trade as their basic market. In the past, we have always been a country that fed its domestic market and sold any excess to export markets. We did not see exports as a primary source of income for business. But, when we see in this budget the EMDG scheme, the DIFF program and a whole range of other support programs attacked as business welfare, we see that the economic rationalists within the Treasury are getting their way with a continuing stream of coalition ministers. These types of programs are not business welfare. They are addressing a market failure in creating an export culture. Because of our OECD membership, we also tend to think that we are a fully developed country. The opposite is true. We are still a developing country, admittedly with a very high standard of living but one that continues to improve. If we do not improve our standard of living, then many people within our society will fall through the net. We have to look forward now and have a look at the safety net itself, to see how it is administered. We have to do so, not because it has failed or because we want to cut funding, but because we want to redirect it to enable Australians to become more part of a productive society. Unless we offer all Australians the right to work we will fail the test set down by this nation. There are ways to create jobs and to do it through our natural resources. Australia is the world's leading mining nation. It is the leader in mining technology and mineral exploration. We are at the forefront of mining technology development. This is, of course, one of our most important sectors. We fail to realise that already we export more goods and services from the mining sector than from the well-publicised wine industry. Quite often, we do not recognise that research and development is taking place in these areas and that Australia is producing world-class goods for export markets. What we need to do is promote them more and ensure that our trade bodies, such as Austrade and Ausmine, are given the support they need. Australia can set the trend. Most people would not realise that the first CD-ROM technology exported by Australia was an adaptation of mining programs on teaching an operator how to use underground equipment. This was, as I said, done on CD-ROM for the first time and exported out of Australia. There are ways, of course, to create new employment. But we need to be forthright and not listen to the economic theorists who tell us what we cannot do rather than what we can do. In December 1995, during discussions I had with a major Japanese paper company, I asked the simple but obvious question of why this particular company had invested in paper production facilities in Canada and other countries but never in Australia. The answer was something of a revelation. It simply was that Australia had never told that particular company that they had to invest in Australia, whereas the Canadians had. 4694 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 18 September 1996 Many ministers have been told you cannot instruct overseas business to construct plant in Australia. The reality is that if you own the natural resource and you want to put a condition down you will get the investment. The Canadians have shown us how to do that. It is now time, I think, that Australia grasped the nettle. That is how we can overcome our trade deficit as well as create new jobs for all Australians. Unfortunately, this budget will not create jobs and will, in fact, add pain to those in the community who are unemployed. What we need is innovation and what we need is new ideas. What we have got in this budget is not just economic rationalism but economic orthodoxy. We have closed CES and DSS offices. With the cutbacks in job programs, with pensioners being hit, with the unemployed being offered no future and with cuts to child care, we can truly say that this government is certainly not governing for all of us. restores Australian families and small businesses in our regions to their pre-eminent position after 13 years of neglect from the former Hawke and Keating governments. In fact, having heard from the speakers today and having two of the guilty party, the member for Fowler( Mr Grace) and the member for Rankin( Mr Beddall), sitting here in this room, it is a pleasure for me to address this hallowed chamber and discuss a couple of matters that came out of the member for Rankin's address. Talk about nowhere to run and nowhere to hide! These two are two of the guilty party. As the member for Rankin said, he watched his people suffer through 13 years of neglect in the seat of Rankin. Why did he not do something about it? As the former minister for small business, for heaven's sake, he was the minister who presided over small businesses in Australia paying 22 per cent interest rates. That was a total failure, not just on his behalf. I noted, as he spoke today, that he still had some good ideas. He was one of the ministers who actually had some good ideas. But his own party walked away from him every time he put those ideas forward, because he actually used some common sense. He actually went to the Japanese and talked to them about how he could get investment in Australia. But he was rejected, along with all those backbenchers and ministers who sat in regional seats. They were ignored by the executive. That is not happening with this government. You saw-and I do not want to be distracted, Mr Deputy Speaker-that historic meeting where the Prime Minister( Mr Howard) brought together all of those people on the woodchip issue. He brought the conservationists together, he brought the industry people together and he brought the interested members of parliament together on the coalition side. They sat down and, very quickly, came up with an idea that is acceptable to the Australian community and provides a great opportunity for jobs in regional Australia. The speech we have just heard from the member for Rankin shocked me. It shocked me in that, once again, they are using scaremongering with the elderly and the most vulnerable in our community. That is a great disappointment to me as the member for McMillan, having suffered through so much of this in my first three years here, watching a government use the scaremongering with the elderly and the vulnerable in our community through the whole of the Fightback package. And now I am seeing them doing exactly the same thing again in opposition. No-one pretends that this was an easy budget to deliver. In fact there must have been this huge sigh of relief in Labor ranks when they lost because they had nowhere to run, nowhere to hide. You heard the member for Perth( Mr Stephen Smith) talk about job programs and
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Broadbent (Mcmillan) (5.58 P.m.)
theText: I rise to speak in support of a budget thatWednesday, 18 September 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4695 denigrate the Prime Minister-as only the Labor Party do-by using language for the member for Bennelong. But I noticed you pulled him up, Mr Deputy Speaker-and I thank you for that-when he called him 'Jobless Johnny'. At the same time the member for Perth said, 'On the other hand-' and what was on the other hand? Nothing. He had no new ideas, no new policies and no hope. What this budget brings to Australia is hope, and it returns to the people the ideas and the aspirations that they have for this nation. I repeat, no-one has pretended it has been an easy budget to deliver. But most of the members on the other side of the House know that, had they been re-elected, they would have been delivering a very similar budget. The decisions and the commitments made were difficult. At the same time, however, one cannot dispute that in this budget the burden of the challenges facing the Australian community has been delivered equitably. The government had no other course, after 13 years of mismanagement of the Australian economy, but to take the action that they have taken and spread the difficulties equally amongst the people. This budget-in my humble opinion-is a tribute to the Prime Minister, John Howard, and to the Treasurer, Peter Costello, for the way they went about the process of fairness and equity to get an outcome like this that is not merely concerned with the next financial year, nor that reflects some pre-occupation with reducing the deficit bequeathed by Labor. This budget is the first step towards retrieving a credible role for government in our community. In the face of growing cynicism and doubt, not only about the function of government but also about the very effectiveness of government itself, this budget establishes the foundations essential to resisting this trend by restoring credibility and honesty with respect to national governments. In recent years we have witnessed the increasing perversion of due process in government. After so many years of incumbency, the former Labor government deluded itself by believing that it could retain power merely by being seen to do something. It overlooked the necessity to actually deliver real outcomes. In my electorate of McMillan prior to the election campaign we had the then local member, Mr Cunningham, announcing in the local paper that he had received $10 million in funding for the electorate. Little has been delivered. We cannot find it in any budget anywhere. Was it just another hollow promise? It is disappointing a whole lot of people around Moe. I noticed that the Opposition Leader( Mr Beazley) actually mentioned funds withdrawn from Moe in Gippsland. There have been no funds withdrawn by this government. In fact, we have delivered exactly what we said we would. We said that, if this was a government commitment that had been signed off, we would do it-and we have done it. We have done it in every regional area. The former government was an administration by style not substance. The dying days of the Keating government can best be described as a shell adorned by labels, such as Working Nation, Creative Nation, Young Nation, One Nation, with little to excuse its failures for 13 years. Labor had even less to justify its sixth term in office. In no other area of public policy was this more manifest than in the proliferation of labour market programs that paid absolutely no regard whatsoever to the effectiveness and performance of such schemes. The former government's own adviser, DEETYA, in its report entitled Working Nation: evaluation of the employment, education and training elements determined after having carried out an assessment of labour market programs that Working Nation had failed by promoting placements in relatively expensive programs that failed to meet the measure of the quality 4696 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 18 September 1996 expected. This report compounded the weight of growing evidence, which the government was electing to ignore, that effectively suggested that government concentrate on delivering real jobs rather than formulating programs. Other reports were compiled with the Economic Planning Advisory Council and the National Board of Employment, Education and Training. The DEETYA report condemned Working Nation for shifting the number of placements away from such effective schemes as the jobclub program to programs such as new work opportunities. Under the new work opportunities program, the employer had no obligation to retain the employee, whereas under wage subsidy programs an incentive was available to encourage the retention of placements. In addition, taking on a trainee was far less expensive under NWO schemes than through many other labour market programs. While the number of placements in wage subsidy programs was intended to increase, there was an evident decline in the number of these positions. For example, in 1993, 26 per cent of program placements were in the jobstart program. That figure fell to 18 per cent in 1994-95 and to 17 per cent in the first eight months of 1995-96. There is ample evidence to suggest that the new work opportunities program was competing for placements in the private sector together with other DEETYA programs. The basis of the more expensive labour market programs was not solely flawed on account of effectiveness. Those programs were placed in areas without, it would appear, any genuine consideration of the priority attaching to such assistance. Administrative data reveals that 15 per cent of all new work opportunities program placements went to the 30 DEETY A areas with the lowest unemployment levels while only 16 per cent of all new work opportunities placements were landed in the 30 DEETYA areas with the highest levels of unemployment. Sufficient time does not exist here to fully trace the failings of Working Nation. What can be said is that Labor has attempted to disguise a policy vacuum with a myriad of programs, distorted incentives and avoided any transparent commitment to real outcomes. In contrast, the transitional and long term initiatives contained in this budget are premised not on programs but on outcomes. They are focused on the individual and not on remote or misbegotten targets. This budget will establish the framework within which the range of labour exchange services can actually be expanded. At the same time those programs that have demonstrated effectiveness will be retained such as new enterprise incentive schemes, NElS, and various English and literacy programs. Regions, like my electorate of McMillan, will benefit by the retention of the Office of Labour Market Adjustment; regional community employment councils, formerly area consultative committees; and the forest industry adjustment package. I note also with very great pleasure the allocation of $48 million towards the finalisation of regional forest agreements. I know that the timber industry, which supports many families in my electorate, will benefit directly from this initiative. It is appropriate at this time to congratulate the government on its decision to lift the woodchip export ceiling by one million tonnes. The decision is much more than the export ceiling; the decision represents country jobs for country people in the electorate of McMillan. Over 1,000 jobs directly depend on this industry in my electorate. Countless other jobs rest upon the activity and employment in the timber industry. I know that employees, management, the NFF, the VFF, the Forest Protection Society and the CFMEU have worked diligently to correct many of the myths surrounding the industry in Australia. Were it not for their Wednesday, 18 September 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4697 confidence in the Howard government, this process would have been rendered far more difficult. It also provides medium to long-term supply security which is so vital to the industry. Many industry representatives in McMillan have long been restricted in their investment decisions by uncertainty as well as the risk of government policy decisions over the years. We have witnessed so many of these. By accelerating the conclusion of RFAs, this budget allows for a stable and sound environment for investment planning. The process that has been outlined by the Prime Minister encourages managers to adopt thinning operations which maximise future sawlog yields in production forests and illustrates the government's commitment to the national forest policy statement as well as value adding in Australia by providing an incentive for woodchip exporters to source their material from sawmills. The modem Australian apprenticeship training scheme guarantees much-needed flexibility that has been absent. We have been neglecting the needs of our young unemployed, not to mention their prospective employers. The wage top-up serves as a safeguard for apprentices, trainees and employers. I have noted with annoyance that the opposition has levelled criticism at the principle of apprentices being paid only for productive time in work. This is a principle which has been accepted by both parties. For the Labor Party to oppose in opposition what it embraced in government is manifestly opportunistic. I tum now to the issue of health. BeforeI do, I will just make my point on how important the woodchip situation is. I will not say who sent me the fax; I will just read out what that fax says. They are talking about an address I made in the House yesterday. It says: I caught up with your spirited defence of the new woodchip regulations. I understand the shadow resources minister, Neil O'Keefe, made his usual destructive contribution on this matter. I appreciate your support for our industry as the past environment has created much uncertainty and has caused much unnecessary hardship in rural Australia. Thanks again. Look forward to catching up with you soon. That is just another person seriously concerned about jobs in regional Australia. I know the member at the table agrees with every word I am saying on this. I come from a position where I cannot believe that you can sit here and be as brazen as you were today in the House during question time when you know that, between 1990 and 1993, you sat there while employment increased 150 per cent. It went from 3,000 to 9,000 in the seat that I formerly held. It is an indictment of you that you can actually sit there and think that we are not going to do the best that we possibly can for those people who are unemployed. We will do it. Everything this government can afford we will do on behalf of those people who are unemployed and genuinely looking for jobs. The health portfolio, better than most, demonstrates Labor's impotence in office. Despite having virtually unlimited resources to effect change, Labor was constrained not only by its industrial wing-to no-one's surprise-but also by a commitment to a version of universality that guaranteed neither access to public health services nor fairness. I suspect Labor consi<hed that, by its commitment to a standard Medicare levy in the absence of private health insurance rebates, it was addressing the current crisis in our public health system. Sadly, its commitment in this regard became a pretext for inaction. Only the coalition has had the courage and the sense of social justice to embrace a two-tiered Medicare system, requiring the wealthy in our community to contribute more to the operation of our public health system. I am sure I would be supported by every member in this room on that issue. The Medicare surcharge for high income earners is an eminently fair measure, 4698 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 18 September 1996 adding perspective to our health system. The long-term maintenance of the public sector depends on greater contributions from higher income earners. The availability of rebates places singles, couples and families in a better position than they enjoyed under Labor. While the availability of rebates for private health cover has been affected by recent increases in health fund premiums, let us remember that the recent increases and impending applications for increases are a direct result of the trend of decline in the number of people taking out private cover. For the opposition to attack the coalition on this front is unforgivable. It is worthy of dismissal for what it really is: a desperate attempt to repair its poor performance in the polls and its poor performance on the health issue. In the establishment of the inquiry by the Productivity Commission into the state of health funds, the government has acted promptly to ensure that the value of these premiums is maintained. In fact, access to health services will be further enhanced in electorates like McMillan. Allowing pharmacies to serve as Medicare agencies will improve access for clients and pensioners in Australia's regions and more remote areas. I am incensed when I hear criticism from the opposition in the wake of our announcement of our intention to reform the aged care sector. It is the height of hypocrisy for a party which introduced an identical system for hostels to now oppose the implementation of the very same system in nursing homes. Unifying the hostel and nursing home system is a measure necessary to address a steadily worsening crisis in nursing home care. In simple terms, nursing homes around the country have not been able to attract sufficient funds to upgrade facilities. Many premises are increasingly dilapidated and fail to meet the standards that we, as a community, should expect for the elderly. In 1994, the then Labor government commissioned a report on the state of nursing homes. After surveying 150 nursing homes, the following findings-amongst others-were made: 75 per cent of homes needed fixing or rebuilding to meet Australian design standards; 13 per cent of homes failed to meet fire authority standards; and 39 per cent of residents were in rooms with four or more beds. The government's objective for aged care is twofold. Firstly, the package allows sufficient funds to address the capital crisis facing many homes; and, secondly, it removes inequities between the nursing home and hostel systems in order that the financially disadvantaged will be protected, while those who can afford to make a contribution will be able do so. Twenty per cent of people who are financially disadvantaged will not be paying to go into a nursing home. They will not be charged $26,000. And everybody on the opposition side knows exactly that. Importantly, full-time pensioners are exempt from having to make any entry contributions. So, too, are financially disadvantaged persons who have not owned a home in the last two years. What people need to understand is that entry contributions, which are established by agreement between management and client, will not be compulsory. While the contribution is to be negotiated between the prospective resident and the proprietor, there are very strict conditions under which arrangements can be finalised. Very secure safeguards exist for the benefit of prospective residents. We should remember that, under the previous government, millionaires enjoyed better access to nursing home beds than the battlers who so conclusively deserted Labor at the last election campaign. For instance, a resident must always be left with assets of at least 250 per cent of the pension-some $22,000-and the entry contribution can only be drawn down at the Wednesday, 18 September 1996 MAIN COMMlTIEE 4699 maximum rate of $2,600 per year for a limit of five years. Members on the other side know that. Most significantly, people will not be forced to sell their own homes at fire sale prices. The same system implemented by Labor for hostels in 1988 will now be applied to nursing homes. While people are given six months to sell their homes, if they fail to do so they cannot be ejected from their accommodation. Their draw-down simply becomes a debt due to the proprietor. A further guarantee exists in that no prospective resident will be asked to make any contribution within the first six months of admission to a nursing home. I do not have the opportunity today to address other issues which are so important and specific in this budget. My community is relieved that the years of the Keating and Hawke governments have gone. We now have the opportunity to build on this budget to make sure that we deliver the promises and the programs that are in it on behalf of the Australian people. I see myself as having had a great blessing in being able to make this address on behalf of the constituents of McMillan. I will serve everyone of them, whichever way they have voted, to the best of my ability. (Time expired) talked about coming from a regional area. McMillan certainly is a region of Victoria. Regional areas were certainly betrayed in this budget-totally betrayed. They were betrayed and abandoned, and the honourable member for McMillan's electorate was abandoned. The Department of Regional Affairs has been gutted-there is no longer a department. The minister has said that there is no clear rational or constitutional basis for Commonwealth involvement in regional development. The minister's statement has wiped out the Department of Regional Affairs. But it is easy to compare what this budget takes away from regional Australia with what Labor had in place. The federal member for Wannon, David Hawker, who is chairman of the Federal Liberal Regional and Rural Committee, said in a press release on 21 July 1995: It is a disgrace that people who choose to work and live in the country often have to put up with the inadequate or non-existent services. While many of the capital cities have started to recover from the hardhitting recession, that recovery has not flowed on to regional areas. I would like to say to David, and to the member for McMillan and all the other members representing regional Australia in this government: 'Let's talk about some of those services.' Let's talk about the Medicare offices which have been closed right around Australia. This budget closed them in regional Australia. And it is no good putting in your rebate claim at the chemist-the chemist does not have a fax machine that can refund you with dollars and cents. Social Security and CES offices have been closed in regional Australia. They are regional services that apply within Australia. They are regional offices right around the country and they are being closed. The tax offices are being closed in Launceston. People in that area have to go all the way to Hobart to talk to somebody in the tax office. That makes things really difficult for older people who like to talk to a tax official on a one-to-one basis. They cannot do it anymore. Bingo! Out it goes. With this budget, this government, out it goes. The Family Court in Launceston is being downgraded. I do not know whether there are other family courts in other parts of regional Australia. If there are, I am sure they are under attack and I am sure they are under pressure of closure. This all happens in regional Australia. The
title: Representatives Main Commitiee

speaker: Mr Adams (Lyons) (6.18 P.m.)
theText: The honourable member for McMillan( Mr Broadbent)4700 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 18 September 1996 honourable member for McMillan( Mr Broadbent) is listening very intently, and so he should, because his region has been betrayed by this budget. University places have been lost in regional universities. In Tasmania, we have lost 380 places from our university. We were very fortunate and we worked very hard-and I know you did too, Mr Deputy Speaker-to increase the opportunities in the northern part of Tasmania and also in the north-west so that, especiaIly in the north-west which has one of the lowest retention rates of tertiary education in Australia, we would have more places for people up there. We have lost that opportunity and those places are now under pressure. Thirty places have been lost at the Australian Maritime College in Launceston. That is a loss to the north of Tasmania. A report I was looking at recently on the economics of northern Tasmania stated that 23 per cent of its economic activity comes from education-university, the Maritime CoIlege, secondary colleges and other educational facilities. So that is a big loss to the state and to that part of Tasmania. Labor's $ I 50 million in infrastructure funding has gone out of the budget. Bingo! It is taken out of the budget; there is no more infrastructure. There was no rational or constitutional basis for that decision, but the minister does not believe that this government has a constitutional or a rational reason for being in anything to do with regional development. The sale of Telstra will affect regional Australia enormously. Tasmania will lose at least 600 jobs for a start, and that is a big loss of incomes for Tasmania. There has been some discussion that digital mobile telephones will be the answer for regional Australia and that regional Australia does not need to have the same services as urban areas. I think this is what is being pushed to all the regional members of the government. They are telling them that mobile phones are the answer for regional Australia. At the moment, 70 per cent of the base stations are located in metropolitan areas, 25 per cent are located in regional areas and five per cent are located in remote areas. I sourced that from answers to a question on notice from the member for Parkes( Mr Cobb) to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government ( Mr Warwick Smith) on 20 August 1996. So only a small proportion of regional Australia currently has access to mobile phones. There will not be an increase in the infrastructure in the less populated areas after privatisation. Even if there was, the mobile phone does not allow the same interactive communication that is available on the Internet or e-mail. It does not allow CD-ROM. It cannot give access to the information systems of the world in the same way that is possible with a physical cable. Without Telstra's current ability to cross-subsidise services, the regional areas will be forgotten and discounted and they will not receive the roll-out of the cable. Tasmania is in a very vulnerable position. I worry greatly about its being able to receive that roll-out. If they do not have this technology, will the individuals, organisations and areas be at an economic disadvantage? It would certainly heighten Tasmania's isolation, as it would with many other regions throughout Australia. Then there is the $600 million sliced off national highway funding. They have pork-barrelled a bit up in the northern part of New South Wales and given the members up there some areasA division having been called in the House of RepresentativesSitting suspended from 6.26 to 6.40 p.m. Wednesday, 18 September 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4701 funding. I think this translates to about $9 million less for Tasmania's highways. Last week the Brew report indicated that they are trying to get rid of our railways. It is a double whammy, of course: they are taking money off the highway system in this budget and closing the national railways in Tasmania, or trying to. There will certainly be a significant loss of work on the Bass Highway and I am sure there are places in the Penguin area and other areas towards the north-west coast where work was being phased in that will probably also be set back. Let us have a look at the loss of the last government's labour market programs, comparing this budget with what was there under a Labor government. These programs were about skill development for long-term unemployed and for young people. It was the opportunity to gain skills through some of these programs. Skillshare is about giving skills to some people who would not get into TAFE, people who would need help with basic literacy and numeracy, basic English, that sort of training, in order to have skills to find a job, to have an opportunity to compete, to have a chance of competing on equal terms with others in that very competitive job market. Those people are going to be denied an opportunity with a 33 per cent cut in the skills hare budget. So there is going to be a reduction in labour market programs, a reduction in chances for people to gain skills, a reduction in opportunities for them to be able to get job ready and a reduction in training for some of those young people who need to come through a program before they can go towards an employer to be taken on board as an employee. You can say that these were Mickey Mouse programs, you can say whatever you wish about them and run them down-which the other side does-but they were programs that were there to assist long-term unemployed and other unemployed. And when we, first as a government and then as an opposition, have sought to find out what this current government would set itself as a target to reduce unemployment, it has refused to tell. So this government has been able to cut $1.8 billion out of labour market programs and it has cut that at the expense of the unemployed, young people, long-term unemployed, people who did have some hope, who had some opportunity to gain skills that would make them somewhat competitive in a very competitive labour market. By cutting that, by getting rid of that, we have reduced the opportunity for a lot of those people. They are to have a test on whether the opportunity to do a course is worthwhile, and it will be very interesting to see how many people are thrown on the scrap heap using that sort of technique. Then there is the ABC. The Launceston office of the ABC and the local programs are under enormous threat, especially in future years. Over the next four years the ABC will lose $209 million-$11 million next year and then $66 million each year for the next three years. Regional Australia has got to take a loss when you start cutting the ABC like that. We are going to have the networking of programs out of Melbourne and Sydney and we are going to lose regional programming right round the country. It will devastate the ABC and will mean the loss in Tasmania, I am sure, of the symphony orchestra. Local programs will disappear and all our news and current affairs will probably come out of Sydney. What relevance does all this have to regional Australia? Those members opposite who represent regional Australia have failed to be able to contribute to the debate within this government. They have failed to take up the issues that are really relevant to regional Australia.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Adams
theText: As I was saying, they have taken $600 million off the national highway4702 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 18 September 1996 There are the losses and changes also to programs, such as the reducing of the tax concession from 150 per cent for research and development to 125 per cent. This puts at risk programs that were being started in our country. For instance, it has recently become technically feasible to treat primary sulphide concentrates by bacterial oxidation to dissolve copper, followed by solvent extraction and electrowinning of the copper. Simply, this is using technology to mine and retrieve the copper concentrate. The new Mount Lyell mine, at Queenstown, is experimenting with producing copper on site rather than sending it overseas to be smelted. This is a new way of smelting, a new technology. This is about smartness. This is about doing things better and differently. This is a good, value adding project, something that we desperately need in my state of Tasmania and in the rest of regional Australia. The project would have three stages over three years in conjunction with BacTech, one of two or three companies in the world who have the technology to treat these copper concentrates in this manner. So here we are, getting on the edge of technology and being knocked over by a really silly, stupid decision of a government trying to play at a political level about something to do with big black holes. This would have meant 30 to 40 jobs and the long-term the viability of this mine, which has to make itself a viable proposition over the next few years. The project is at risk. Why? Because this government really is not looking at the future. It did not have any vision in this budget. When I have heard members from the other side speak in the budget debate on the appropriations bill here, all they have wanted to do is to attack this side of the House. They want to attack the previous government but lack putting much vision into the future. They have failed to be able to go in there and take on the Treasurer ( Mr Costello) and the executive of this government, and to be able in any way to influence this. All those members who have come in from regional Australia have been walked over, and regional Australia has been the loser. The betrayal of the private sector, which is taking risks for the future, is a really silly decision. The government has a vital role to play in facilitating this and should have been in there doing it. Then there is the loss of the $150 million in infrastructure funding, putting other projects at risk. Orielton Lagoon, in southern Tasmania, is at risk. There is an irrigation scheme here and an effluent recycling project. The feasibility study showed the export opportunities for farmers involved in new crops in this area. In my electorate, just over from the airport of southern Tasmania, there are close opportunities for cherry farming, for intensive farming, taking water out of a recycling sewage farm and putting that water on to the golf club, selling the water to the golf club, selling it to farmers. The feasibility study has been done, all the engineering is done and all we needed was a bit of capital to make it happen. Of course, bingo: $150 million infrastructure funds for regional Australia, bingo. 'No constitutional responsibility,' says the minister. I turn to the shipbuilding bounty. Everybody knows the Incat success story in Tasmania. Some of the rewards that we have there are at risk. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Senator Vanstone) talks about real jobs. Real jobs have been created there, with new jobs in welding and aluminium product, and very new skills have been founded. A lot of work has gone into building up the skill base. The bounty was reviewed in February 1995 and the report found that the industry had totally transformed itself in the 1980s from a domestic situation to export, and about 80 per cent of Wednesday, 18 September 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4703 the production is now exported. Why change a success story? It is very hard to understand and it is just a stupid decision by government to do so. Then there is the hydrodynamic facility at the maritime college in northern Tasmania. This would have been a world class third-generation ocean testing basin. It would have put Australia at the forefront of this type of research. The sort of research that they are doing there in the maritime college is work on the platforms for the oil rigs that are now being made in Australia at Bunbury, I think, in Western Australia and at Newcastle on the east coast. The technology for these things has been developed in the test tanks at the maritime college in Launceston. Fourteen million dollars would have given us a facility that would have put us at the leading edge of technology, but that has been knocked back by this government, using this budget. So the honourable member representing that region has failed that region miserably. I could go on. I have not touched on things like funding to the state governments for programs such as housing, dental care, child care, superannuation, elderly care-all these programs that really matter to families. Government members have been quite forceful in saying that they represent families. Families are the basis of all those programs that are affected by the cuts in this budget. The families will feel the disappointment, the let-down, of the many broken promises. The government has been very short-sighted in this budget. It has failed to give a vision, a hope, to many different groups within the community that were probably thinking that with a new government there would be new opportunities and we would get some vision. But the government wanted to play around with the politics of the edge. They talked about a $9 billion deficit, black holes, et cetera. But they offered no vision to our industries or opportunities to help the long-term unemployed by putting in place the programs that needed to be put in place. This government is wishy-washy. It does not have a clue about how to stimulate job creation in this economy. It has failed. Its ministers are in disarray in the other place. The minister in our House is talking about trying to get the number of apprentices up, but he does not even know in which industries he is going to get the apprentices up. Australia has been betrayed. Regional Australia has been abandoned, betrayed, forgotten and run away from by all those members on the other side who came in from regional Australia. It is a shame, and they should be ashamed that they have let down their electorates. (Time expired) me tonight I would like to make a few points relating to the previous speaker, the honourable member for Lyons( Mr Adams). First of all, let me say that 77 per cent of the Australian population have already spoken. They have told us that they believe this is a fair, equitable and responsible budget, which is something that has not been achieved in my memory and certainly not in the last l3 years. I will make a couple of quick comments regarding his last remarks. I noted down on the pad in front of me the words 'short-sighted approach'. I think that is exactly what the Labor Party had. The fact that they were willing to sell the future by overspending now indicated quite rightly that they had no long-term vision. In fact, they were quite prepared to sell off the farm. They were quite prepared to go further into debt in order to fulfil their short-term goals rather than to look at the long term. They talk about the failure of the minister for employment. That is hypocrisy at its best. Six months we have been here. The Telstra bill, the industrial relations bill and the budget-the
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Brough (Longman) (6.52 P.m.)
theText: Mr Deputy Speaker, in the short time available to4704 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 18 September 1996 things with which we went to the people-are not yet through the parliament. When the legislation is passed and they have had time to be put into place and to have an effect, we will see real jobs created. I think that we are going to pay the price for taking an honest approach to government. We saw in the lead-up to the last election so many people being put into jobs. I should say 'into outcomes'. They are not jobs; they are long-term training projects. They enable people to come off the long-term unemployment list and on to the short-term unemployment list. They do not create a job; they do not create any wealth for Australia; they do not give these people any hope. They simply made the government of the day look better. I will perhaps leave to my second instalment my other comments regarding the budget, which the greater percentage of Australians acknowledge was the correct measure to take. I make reference to A fair go for families, a publication put out by the Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission. This is to pre-empt the debate that will take place in the main chamber perhaps tomorrow in relation to the family tax laws. It states: A simple method of moving towards a fairer taxation system for families would be to introduce additional tax thresholds in respect of dependents. That is exactly what this government has done. It goes on: This would recognise the additional minimum costs incurred by families with dependents. This publication of 1987 was available to the previous Labor government for some eight years, yet it never took it up. In our first term we have taken it up and on 1 January of this year we will see those tax cuts come into effect. There are two issues I would like to address in the very short time available. The first one is aged care in my own electorate of Longman. Aged Care Queensland has put a submission together which will be going to the federal and state ministers for family services in the next few days. This submission identifies particular areas of Longman as being the most disadvantaged areas when it comes to nursing homes. The area of Bribie Island in particular is one which has seen a great deal of growth, particularly for elderly people as they move there for the fishing, the beaches, the fine weather and, of course, the quiet lifestyle. It has also resulted in the fact that we have only 50 places in total, provided by one nursing home, for the entire population. The population of people aged 70 and over is some 3,000 to 4,000. This means that in reality, to be able to meet the criteria, we should have somewhere between 300 and 400 nursing home places and we have 50. The situation in Caboolture is no better. In the past the whole approach to nursing home places has been totally misdirected. We have talked of regions, and Bribie Island and Caboolture come into a planning region called Cabool. Pine Rivers Shire is also part of that particular region. That helps to equalise the numbers. It means that through this process we have been unable to deliver the places where they are needed and where the elderly population wish to live. We do not, unfortunately, have a large population. The Gold Coast, known as the south coast region, has 3,021 aged care places for a population of 30,939 over 70 years of age. This means that they are underserviced by only 73 places. In the area of Cabool, we are 224 places underserviced. If we were fully serviced just in the Bribie-Caboolture area alone, all of those places would be taken. Wednesday, 18 September 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4705 I am reassured by Aged Care Queensland that they are recommending 30 places be allocated to Caboolture and 70 to Bribie Island to bolster the already high quality establishments that are there, such as the Bribie Island Retirement Village and the War Veterans' Home at Caboolture, not to mention Sunnymead Nursing Home. Finally, I would like to bring to the committee's attention the plight of the Autistic Association of Queensland. I have been meeting today with two people, Mr Bruce Faye, the President of the Autism Association of Queensland, and Carol Renard. Of all the areas of special needs, this particular group is probably the most disadvantaged because, as these people pointed out to the minister and myself today, if you have in this room people suffering from perhaps Down Syndrome, it is quite obvious. Their impediments can be seen and it is very obvious visually. People with autism look just like you and me. The fact is that the needs they have are very much specialised. They need additional care. Unfortunately, in Queensland at this stage we have an absolute lack of people available to service the parents, the school teachers and the carers, as well as the children who suffer from autism. Whilst people with autism look 100 per cent healthy, their behavioural patterns and ability to communicate are often extremely lacking. The additional care they require is imperative if the families are going to have any quality of life and if the teachers are able to assist them, in particular in regional Queensland where we have one staff member looking after more than 400 families with autistic children. I seek leave to continue my remarks later. Leave granted; debate adjourned.
